PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that the introduction of tuition fees for post-graduate and second degree students will:

(i) severely limit access to such levels of study. The ability of a student to pay tuition fees will be the main criterion for entry to such courses. The restricted availability of Commonwealth post-graduate scholarships and the difficulty of finding part time work in employment related areas further restricts the ability of post-graduate students to pay tuition fees.

(ii) result in higher attrition rates in post-graduate and second degree studies. Recent surveys have indicated that up to 50 per cent of students would be unable to continue their studies if tuition fees at the level of $1,000 per year were introduced. Inability to continue study is both a personal tragedy and a waste of the community's resources.

(iii) limit Australia's capacity to cope with technological, economic and social change. Many degree students who will have to pay tuition fees undertake further study to upgrade their qualifications to cope with changes in their area of employment. Many are forced to undertake retraining in areas outside their current employment because of declining job opportunities in such areas due to economic change. Further study for many students will bring no financial benefit but simply allow them to extend their contribution in the course of their work. For example, thousands of teachers have undertaken further study to gain expertise in such areas as migrant education, remedial literacy and numeracy teaching, curriculum development, and so on.

(iv) further restrict access to such study for women students. As a result of the abolition of tuition fees the proportion of women students in tertiary education has increased significantly. Mature age women students have benefited by the opportunity denied them when they left school.

(v) seriously undermine Australia's research effort. Approximately 22 per cent of Australian research takes place in tertiary institutions. The bulk of Australia's basic research is undertaken in universities. The introduction of tuition fees threatens Australia's capacity to cope with major structural change in the economy.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate will reject the introduction of tuition fees.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Will the Minister advise whether the Government will accept the report of the IAC and, if so, whether speedy implementation can be made of the recommendation to lift duty under tariff item 71.14 from 2 per cent to 25 per cent to prevent some importers from taking advantage of what seems to be an anomaly in tariff provisions covering the importation of gold chain?

It is true that the Industries Assistance Commission did recommend a change in the rate of duty applicable to precious metal chain-2 per cent-as distinct from that chain which constitutes jewellery, to which a tariff of some 25 per cent applies. The Government has decided to accept the recommendation in the report and has applied the higher rate to precious metal chain since 30 October. I understand that that was the date upon which the announcement was made. I will check for the information of the honourable senator whether that was the actual date of implementation of the new decision.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL SYSTEM: INTEREST RATES ON HOUSING LOANS

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister representing the Treasurer confirm that housing interest rates have increased four times in the last 16 months to an all-time nominal and real high? Will the Minister also confirm that this increase in mortgage interest rates has cost persons, with the common 30-year $30,000 home loan, $65 a month while average weekly earnings have increased in the same period by just over $30 a month? I refer the Minister to statistics which show that in the December quarter of 1975, when average weekly earnings were $167 a week and the median house price in Sydney was $33,500, the value of a house was 200 times average weekly earnings, whereas for the same quarter in 1981 it was 283 times average weekly earnings? I further refer the Minister to statistics which show that after five years of her Government's policies, families with a typical household loan of $30,000 over 30 years at 12 1/2 per cent interest need to make repayments of $320 a month.
—Order! I suggest to the honourable senator that he is giving a lot of information in the course of asking a question. I suggest that he watch that position very carefully. He may proceed.

—Accordingly, those people need an income of approximately $300 a week, an income which is denied almost 80 per cent of Australian employees. I ask the Minister whether, in the light of this, she will agree that there is overwhelming evidence that her Government's policies have reduced the Australian dream home to just that-a dream home. In view of public concern, as is evidenced by the 57,000 signatures raised against high interest rates in South Australia in recent weeks, and in view of the disquiet instilled in home buyers by the recommendations in the report of the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Austalian Financial System, can the Minister, firstly, give an assurance that home loan lending rates will not increase as a consequence of the Government's response to the Campbell Committee report and, secondly, advise the Senate how long the Government will deny effective assistance to home buyers?

—Before I call the Minister, I inform her that, because of the type of question asked and the amount of rather technical information required, if she wishes to have the question placed on notice she is at liberty to do so.
—That would apply to all Government questions.
—That is not so. The same applied yesterday. I call Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — A great deal of information and many figures were given in the question. I am not able to confirm the accuracy of the figures expressed by Senator Bolkus. However, he did make comparisons of figures over the last five years for income levels and the repayments that are required to be made. Again, I am not able to verify the figures that he presented. Although we are concerned about the level of interest rates, there are some interesting statistics which show, in relation to the repayments that need to be made by prospective home buyers, that the prices of both houses and land have increased considerably. The proportion of income that is reflected in repayments related to those costs should also be of concern to us all, quite separately from the interest rate problem. The matter of home ownership is of primary importance to this Government and I think of concern to all Australians who wish to see that there is the capacity for home ownership by as many families in this country as is possible. Our record in this country is significant in comparison with other countries. However, I will ask the Treasurer to look at the figures and the facts that have been provided by the honourable senator and see what information can be given in response to them. But I suggest that he might, if he is interested in figures, analyse what has happened to the price of land and the price of building houses as well as look at interest rates, in considering the incidence of the increase in repayments.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the Campbell report, my colleague the Treasurer made it clear yesterday that this report is under study by a committee which will work on the report for the Government. Before any decisions are taken on that report the Government will, of course, have in its own mind its social policies and its political approach to many of the things that have become established policy in this country. I think we should await the outcome of that study and the Government's response to the Campbell report before we draw the sorts of conclusions that people seem to have been drawing in the last 24 hours or so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Communications to a statement I received today from Telecom Australia which shows that Telecom will soon be able to issue to small businesses throughout Australia telephones with many advanced capabilities, some of which I hope will gradually become available to ordinary subscribers. Whilst I am pleased to see Telecom progressing in the area of services to businesses, I must ask: When will Telecom install the system which will detail on subscribers' accounts the details of subscriber trunk dialling calls so that subscribers who query their accounts can have some basis for their argument against the might of Telecom which, from my observations, still does not give subscribers the benefit of the doubt over disputed accounts?

—Although I have not seen the release that Senator Townley said he received today, I am aware that a new telephone set is likely to become available and that it will have automatic dialling and other capabilities which many consumers will want to use. I will seek more information on that. I will have to refer to the Minister Senator Townley's question on the progress of the inquiries about a monitor system for STD calls. I undertake to do that and to report back to the honourable senator.

—I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Having regard to the defence risks to the people of Darwin, including the presence of B52 bombers, the increasing noise pollution caused by the present location of Darwin Airport and the availability of suitable land to the south of the city, will the Government, before allocating additional funds for the upgrading of Darwin Airport, undertake an analysis of the economic and social advantages of relocating the airport to a less populated area and hold a public inquiry into the relationship between the future development of Darwin and its air transport needs?
—I will refer that question to the responsible Minister.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health, firstly, whether tuberculosis is at present a notifiable disease and, if figures are available, whether there has been any marked increase in the incidence of TB in recent times. Secondly, can the Minister give the details of any anti-TB program funded by the Government?

—I know that tuberculosis used to be a notifiable disease. It certainly was at the time I was involved in the care of patients with this illness. I know of no reason why it would not continue to be notifiable. I am aware, of course, that it has diminished considerably as a health risk in this country. I am also aware that in 1976 the Government handed control of tuberculosis to the States. The special Commonwealth program that began in 1949 made Australia the country at that stage with the best control of tuberculosis in the world. It was thought appropriate at that stage to hand control of tuberculosis to the States, which have direct management of hospital and other services. I am not aware of any significant increase in the figures for tuberculosis since 1971. In that year there were 11.6 new cases per 100,000 and in 1980 the figure was 10.7 new cases per 100,000. I recall a recent Press report which gave some extraordinary assertion of a 20 or 30 per cent incidence among certain disadvantaged groups. I know of no basis for those figures, and as far as I know they are quite incorrect.
—What sort of groups?

—I think it was referring to unemployed persons, for example, and figures of 20 to 30 per cent are quite obviously incorrect and outrageous. The population in Australia is ageing and it may be that there could still be some detection of people who have had long standing tuberculosis. Age rates for tuberculosis were first collected in 1975, and the rates then for elderly people, say between 65 and 70 years old, were about 7.5 per 100,000. In 1980 that figure was 21.4 per 100,000. But I emphasise again that the overall figures in Australia are not rising. There is no evidence of any increased incidence of tuberculosis. I repeat that we achieved the best figures in the world by dint of a very active program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CORRESPONDENTS AND CAMERA CREWS: SPECIAL INSURANCE COVER

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. I refer to a report in the Sydney Sun newspaper that camera crews employed by commercial radio, television stations and newspapers have won special insurance cover for working in danger zones and will now be insured by employers for $150,000 in the event of death or permanent disability. Is the Government continuing its refusal to allow the Australian Broadcasting Commission to insure correspondents and camera crews on hazardous assignments? Is the Minister aware of approaches by the Australian Journalists Association, the Australian Broadcasting Commission Staff Association and the ABC to allow the ABC to insure its personnel? Has the matter been before an interdepartmental committee? If so, has the committee finished its deliberations? If it has, when will the Government make an announcement on the matter that has been before it since the death of Tony Joyce?

—I would be grateful if Senator Sibraa could make available to the Minister those details he has of the arrangements which have been put in train for commercial station employees. I do not have details of approaches from the AJA or the ABC Staff Association. I am sure they would be matters which my colleague would have in his hands. The matter of whether there has been an interdepartmental committee meeting will also have to be referred to the Minister. I undertake so to do.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noticed an Australian Bureau of Statistics information paper which deals with 1981 census data release plans in which the Bureau lists a number of information papers and topic information papers which deal with a variety of topics which relate to the 1981 census? These papers deal with subjects such as industry, occupation, income, language and Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders but omit a very important subject on data collected by the last census on overseas born Australians. Will the Minister ask the Treasurer to ensure that the Bureau issues a topic information paper on that subject which would be of immense value to all Government departments which deal with migrants and their problems?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am not sure whether the information referred to by Senator Lajovic is readily available in the Australian Bureau of Statistics, but I have no hesitation in referring the question to the Treasurer to see whether it would be possible for a paper to be prepared along the lines suggested by the honourable senator. If that is so, I will ask the Treasurer to give it his earliest attention.

—I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Is the Government aware of reports that the Bjelke-Petersen Government is presently considering a proposal that would make Queensland an on-shore stamp duty haven with the State forgoing around $280m a year in revenue in a move designed to have businesses from around Australia stampeding into Queensland to consummate their transactions? What is the Government's attitude not only to the national economic implications of any such move but also more particularly to the inequities and distortions that any such change, such as the competitive phasing out of probate duty before it, would inevitably introduce into the present national tax collection and revenue distribution arrangements? Will the Government take measures to dissuade Queensland from any such move-for example, responding to the State's apparent willingness to forgo some revenue by reducing the Commonwealth general purpose grants otherwise payable to that State?

—If the last part of the question is asking whether we would use the tax revenue sharing device as a punitive weapon, the answer is no. Also, I would reject the concept that it was a bad thing to phase out probate duties. I imagine that every family in Australia welcomes the fact that probate duties were phased out. From time to time there will inevitably be competition between the States as to methods of incentive to stimulate business within the States. It would not be the task of a Commonwealth government to decide what a sovereign State government might or might not do. That is the kind of paternalism of the socialists, which we reject. I am not aware of the proposal to set aside stamp duty. I will have a look at the matter. But I imagine that the Commonwealth Government would regard that as something that was a proper decision for a State to make. The taxing abilities of the States and the way in which they raise their revenue is taken into account by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. In the end, overall adjustments are made, particularly in the longer run, with Queensland which has been a claimant State.

—I thank the Minister representing the Minister for Education for his answer last week on the O'Brien case at the University of Western Australia. In view of the large commitment of Commonwealth money to the University of Western Australia I ask the Minister further on the O'Brien case whether he will obtain through his colleague in the other place detailed statements of the assets of the University of Western Australia. Will the Minister see that no Commonwealth funds are used to defray costs in the O'Brien case? Will the Minister inquire whether this case was one of the causes of the resignation of the former Chancellor, Sir Lawrence Jackson, and finally, whether the report of the O'Brien case given to the University Senate recently by Vice-Chancellor Street bears so little resemblance to the remarks in court of magistrate Sir Clifford Grant as to be almost a travesty?

—The questions that have been asked of me by Senator Martyr invite information which I do not have available. I well recall his question to me recently. I well recall the remarks of the magistrate who said that it was a very inappropriate case to be brought to the courts and that the university ought to settle its problems outside the courts. The honourable senator asked a number of questions concerning assets and the reasons for a vice-chancellor taking certain action. I will refer those questions to my colleague the Minister for Education in another place for his study.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. By way of preface I point out that in the other place on 22 September, as reported on page 1585 of Hansard, Mr Anthony, when defending the Minister for Communications, Mr Sinclair, from charges made in the Senate committee report on the Australian Dairy Corporation, said:

QUESTION.PARA: The Department--
That is the Department of Primary Industry-
has not blundered. If it did anything wrong, it was because it was conned by some very clever and very skilled people in the Australian Dairy Corporation . . .
I ask: Who were these people in the Australian Dairy Corporation and what exactly did they do?

TALK.START.PARA: —That question will have to be referred to the Minister for Trade and Resources since it asks about matters that arise out of a comment made by him. I will see that that is done.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Education. I refer to the Commonwealth Government announcement that any student loans scheme envisaged to be dependent on the co-operation of the banks to finance the scheme has now been shelved indefinitely by the Government. Accordingly, I ask: Noting that the Butcher committee report on student loans made a distinction between two kinds of loans scheme-the smaller one envisaging loans up to an average of about $500 and fully administered by individual universities and colleges for the most needy students and a second scheme which would allow for much larger loans, have long-term repayments and be administered by the banks-will the Government consider immediate implementation of a loans scheme of this first and smaller kind by distributing about $3m to universities and colleges for this purpose before January 1982? Finally, noting not only the present impasse in negotiations with the banks but also the intrinsic weaknesses and disadvantages of the larger kind of student loans scheme, will the Government now go on forthrightly to announce that this second type of loans scheme will not be implemented?

—I well recall the Butcher committee; indeed, I set up that committee when I held the education portfolio. Well before the Butcher committee there was in practice-I think this remains in practice-in universities and colleges a small loans scheme of a recycling type. Those loans were referred to as maundy money. I do not know what is the total volume; I thought it was of the order of $2m or $3m of recycled funds. I am not aware of how much is currently being recycled. I will check and I will draw the Minister's attention to that. I know that there have been some considerable difficulties in negotiating with the lending institutions the second type of scheme and some people criticise the scheme as having difficulties. I am not aware that the Commonwealth has put it aside. I understand that it was still under study to see whether it could be implemented. I note Senator Teague's comments and I will bring them to the attention of the Minister for Education.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs aware of recent reports that claim that large numbers of prisoners are being held by the Ugandan military police without charges being laid? Is she aware that according to one report the prisoners' ages range from 12 to 80 years, they are dressed in rags, are allowed no visitors, are locked up 24 hours a day and are being denied medical treatment? Will the Minister advise whether there has been an expression of concern by the Australian Government that human rights are being denied by the Ugandan Government especially in relation to the young and the aged? In particular, will the Minister establish the exact whereabouts and physical condition of two former Ministers, Jaberi Bidandi-Sali and the Reverend Christopher Okoth, last heard of in Luzira Prison in August this year?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have some information relating to political prisoners in Uganda. Some of Senator Coleman's questions may have to be referred to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Press reports published concerning political prisoners in Uganda have led the Minister for Foreign Affairs to state that if these reports are verified this would be a matter of grave concern to the international community, including Australia. The Government attaches importance to the protection of human rights and is concerned about reports of violations of those rights wherever they may occur. Australia has sought to monitor developments in Uganda since the elections in December 1980 which resulted in the return of Dr Obote to the Ugandan leadership. Australia is sympathetic to the immense problems confronted by Dr Obote's Government in restoring Uganda to its former peace and prosperity. Progress has been slow but there are indications that the Government is making some headway in its efforts to re-establish law and order and to overcome the serious economic difficulties which confront the Government after years of misrule and chronic violence. It is our earnest hope that the Ugandan Government will be able to continue to make progress and to overcome its current difficulties without resorting to harsh and repressive measures.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Foreign Affairs has informed me that he has instructed the Australian High Commission in Nairobi to make inquiries concerning these reports, which were the ones mentioned by Senator Coleman, during the next visit to Uganda by Australian representatives. I might also add that within the context of our aid program in Africa, Australia is doing what it can to assist the Ugandan Government's efforts. We participated in the Commonwealth group which observed the Ugandan elections. In April this year the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced that Australia would provide $1.5m in famine relief and more recently, following discussions held with Ugandan officials at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting, the Government decided to provide additional assistance to Uganda in the form of food aid and commodity support to the value of $2.4m. The Government is currently examining possible additional assistance to Uganda. As I said, with regard to some of the more specific matters raised by Senator Coleman, I will see what early information I can have provided for her.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. Will the Minister advise whether there has been any recent approach by Australia Post to increase still further rural newspaper postage rates? Will he assure the Parliament of his opposition to any such increase and affirm the vital role that the minor Press plays in non-metropolitan Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have no difficulty in endorsing the role which the Press plays in non-metropolitan Australia-and when Senator Archer says 'the minor Press' I take it he means the local and provincial Press in that area-in the same way as I recognise the role which the other media have to play in non-metropolitan Australia as a vital form of communication. I am advised that the Postal Services Act requires the Australian Postal Commission to recover by way of its charging policies at least 50 per cent of the cost of its capital expenditure. It has to construct its charges on that basis. Unless otherwise determined by the Government postal charges have to be set so that the users of the services generally pay the cost of providing them.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I am aware that there was earlier this year an announcement of an increased postage rate. I think the increase was announced some time in June and that it was the first rise that had been announced for several years. But I am not aware of and I do not believe that there has been any subsequent suggestion that there is to be any increase in postal rates. I believe the Australian Postal Commission has not raised that matter with the Minister whom I represent. To that extent I think the honourable senator can dismiss the rumours as being unfounded.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN EQUITY IN RESOURCE DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen reports of the address given on Monday by the Secretary to the Treasury, Mr John Stone, which suggested that Mr Stone argued that public assistance for housing, health, education and welfare would have to be sacrificed if we were to see greater Australian equity in resource development projects? Will the Government make its position clear on these statements from its most senior economic adviser? If not, can we assume that these views also represent the views of the Australian Government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I did see some Press reports of Mr Stone's address given, I think, earlier this week but I do not have any comments from the Treasurer on the matter. I will refer the question to him to see whether there is any comment that he wishes to make.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. I draw the Minister's attention to the abundance of camels in the Northern Territory and to the fact that export camel meat is classified as game meat and is therefore required to be processed through a registered game meat export establishment. There are no game meat export abattoirs in the Northern Territory. As this industry could be one of significance in the Northern Territory, employing members of Aboriginal communities and providing an alternative source of income, will the Government reconsider classification of camel meat with a view to amending the regulations to allow camels to be slaughtered for export under normal conditions, as for beef, at local abattoirs?

—That seems to me to be a very touchy question in light of the recent history of the meat industry and the meat export industry in particular. In balmier days when they were less troubled I probably would have answered the question by saying: 'I am game, if you are'. In the circumstances I will refer the question to the Minister for Primary Industry for a more expert reply.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It relates very much to the question just answered by Senator Baume. I ask the Leader whether it is a fact that this year the Government raised the interest rates payable on outstanding long term loans to Telecom Australia and Australia Post, which had previously been at a fixed rate of interest, causing a degree of chaos in those organisations and higher charges to Australian consumers for the services of both organisations. Will the Government consider raising the interest rates payable on loans to two people whose incomes and financial positions are much healthier than the average Australian-namely, Mr Anthony and Mr Nixon?
—I will refer both those questions to the appropriate Ministers and seek their consideration.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to Mr Macphee's Press statement relating to the six men claiming to be Indian nationals and to have been cast ashore after 15 days at sea who were detected on 6 November 1981 on Irvine Island off the Western Australian coast. Inasmuch as these people landed on Irvine Island without previous detection, in excellent health and immaculately dressed, wearing the very best and latest in summer gear, could the Minister tell the Senate what off-shore and on-shore surveillance is undertaken along the north-west coast of Western Australia? Given the proximity of our north-west coast to the loosely described Golden Triangle region, notorious for its growing and supplying of drugs, will the Minister tell the Senate whether he considers the surveillance adequate and if not, what plans are in hand to strengthen it? I conclude by asking whether the Minister will assure the Senate that the circumstances of these gentlemen's arrival will be thoroughly investigated and that prosecutaons will take place if any offences have been committed relating to both the arrival and transport of these gentlemen to Australia?
—I will refer that question to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and ask him to give an early answer to the honourable senator.

—My question without notice is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications. The Minister will be aware that Lord Howe Island and its 200-odd residents are to get a modern telephone service as a result of Minister Sinclair's intervention. Will the Minister now take appropriate steps to ensure that after 16 years of battling for a decent communications system the 2,000 residents of Palm Island-much closer to the Queensland coast than is Lord Howe Island-also has a decent telephone service? Is the Minister also aware that the Gulf shires of Burke and Croydon have such a primitive telephone system that it is faster to send messages by carrier pigeon than to use a telephone? Can some of the Lord Howe Island funds be redirected to update telephone services in these two shires?

—Last week I was in Burke Shire and met there also with representatives of Carpentaria Shire. They raised a number of matters with me, including their communications problems. I will undertake to make known to my colleague Senator Keeffe's concern about the communications problem on Palm Island and also his desire that the two shires he mentioned should also have access to better communication. I just add that the Clerk of Burke Shire, Mr Allan Choveaux, is one of the best communicators and one of the best boosters of his own shire that I know anywhere around Australia.
—Do you have a passport?
—I understand that is in the mail. I understand that Mr Choveaux has also made known the problems in that Shire. I will pass the matter on to the Minister as well.
—I ask a supplementary question. I appreciate the Minister's reply but I also remind him that with the onset of the wet season those telephones do not work at all.
—I will pass on that extra information.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce. Will consideration be given for some of the offset work flowing from the FA18 contract planned for the Government Aircraft Factories to go to the Launceston Precision Tool Annex, a highly skilled workshop in Launceston, which is currently successfully undertaking work for the the United States Navy?
—I will refer that matter to Sir Phillip Lynch for consideration and reply to the honourable senator.

—Mr President, last Sunday the Deputy Prime Minister claimed that Labor's toads, as he called them, had been smearing National Country Party Ministers with what he said were distortions and lies. Can the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources tell us which, if any, of the following are distortions or lies: That Mr Anthony has a 4 3/4 per cent government loan; that Mr Nixon has a 6 1/2 per cent government loan; that a bipartisan Senate committee unanimously stated that it preferred Mr Webster's evidence to Mr Sinclair's evidence; that there was a meat export scandal; and that Mr Sinclair still has $200,000 which he has stated was stolen from the Walsh companies? If none of those are distortions or lies, precisely what did the Deputy Prime Minister have in mind when he made his claim?
—Mr President, as the question is one that only the Minister for Trade and Resources can answer, I suggest that Senator Walsh place his question on notice and get his answer that way.

—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Mr President, am I to take it that the Leader of the Government in the Senate is refusing to submit my question to Mr Anthony and ultimately to supply an answer to the Senate? I might add that once before I was asked to follow such a procedure and when I put the question on notice with more detail, as had been requested, the question was ruled out of order as a question on notice. My supplementary question is: Is the Minister refusing to pass on that question to Mr Anthony for answer ultimately in the Senate?

—Mr President, on the contrary, I am suggesting the procedure which should be followed by any honourable senator who seeks a direct response from a Minister in the other place on what that Minister is alleged to have said; that is, that the question should be placed on notice.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Transport aware that AIC Q5-1981, which prohibits the use of Brisbane Airport between 2100 and 2415 hours eastern standard time, is being abused by the Department of Transport insofar as it demands that aircraft departing Brisbane Airport have to be 90 nautical miles away at 9 p.m., which means that they must be taxiing by 8.40 p.m.? Is the Minister aware that a NOTAM, a notice to airmen, to the effect that Mackay Airport is now to be closed at 8.40 p.m. on a Friday night has been issued? I ask: Why cannot regular public transport jet aircraft operate into those airports where air traffic control staff are not on duty, as they have for years into Gove without any incident whatsoever? How can the Government tolerate a double standard from the Department on this point? Will the Minister, as a matter of urgency, instruct the Department of Transport that it cannot inflict the economic consequences of its mismanagement on the economy of one State of the Commonwealth in isolation? How much does the Minister estimate that fares Australia-wide will rise as a result of the lack of use of aircraft coming into these airports because of these limitations?
—I ask Senator MacGibbon to put that question on notice.

—I address my question to the Minister for Social Security. In reply to a question regarding the hire of Telecom Australia devices, such as the porta-printer for handicapped people, the Minister for Communications indicated that, although Telecom was increasing the availability of such products for handicapped people, the financial assistance for such facilities should be funded through a social security program. I ask the Minister: As disabled people should have equal rights to communications services, will his Department fund the hire of facilities at a fee disabled people can afford?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the potential value of the porta-printer device for the profoundly deaf. It is a device which can be attached to a normal telephone and which provides a printout. It is, therefore, something which can greatly expand the communications ability of those who suffer from profound deafness. The value of the machines depends upon there being a network of them. A single porta-printer is of no use. It has to work in conjunction with a porta-printer which is at the other end of the telephone call. As a contribution to establishing a network of porta-printer devices at useful centres, my Department has taken the initiative of installing a porta-printer at an office of the Department in each State and is arranging to centralise the records of the profoundly deaf at that office so that all profoundly deaf clients of the Department, if they have the porta-printer device, will be able to access into my Department. We have drawn this development to the attention of other Commonwealth departments. I hope that other departments will be able to make similar provision in the future.

ANSWER.PARA: We have also examined the point which was specifically raised by the honourable senator; that is, the availability of the device to individual people who are profoundly deaf. My recollection is that at the moment the cost of installation is of the order of $900. I do understand that that can be a very considerable cost for many people who are disabled. At the moment the only people who qualify for assistance through the Department of Social Security are those who are receiving assistance through the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service; that means people who are getting assistance with a view to increasing their employability. There is no general program which would provide a subsidy for the machine to be obtained by others. Again I speak from recollection, but the last step taken by me was to raise the matter with the Minister for Health, who has responsibility for the Aids for the Disabled Program which was recently instituted by the Commonwealth. Many honourable senators would be aware that that program is still to go into operation in New South Wales. It is in operation in other States. It is very early in the life of that program, but I have drawn the particular mechanism to the attention of the Minister for Health and have asked him to examine whether assistance might be provided with respect to its being obtained by individuals in the community.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Transport whether he has noted a report, which appeared on page 3 of yesterday's Advertiser, about the Australian Automobile Dealers Association's annual convention. Does the Minister agree with the Association's claim that the Australian road system is 'becoming increasingly inadequate' and that this situation is 'wholly attributable to the Commonwealth's present road funding programs'? What does the Government intend to do to ensure that the 3 per cent to 4 per cent of road stock that needs replacing each year is replaced? Is it a fact that presently only 1.5 per cent to 2 per cent of road stock is being replaced under the present funding programs? Having regard to Australia's vast continent with a small population and a sparse settlement pattern, can the Minister give an assurance that a high priority will be placed on the provision of funds for the construction and upkeep of roads?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not have available to it any independent source of information to confirm the points raised by Senator Jessop and referred to by the Australian Automobile Dealers Association yesterday. However, the Minister has indicated his awareness of the claim that the Australian road system is becoming increasingly inadequate to handle current and projected traffic demands. Relevant studies are being undertaken at present by the Bureau of Transport Economics. Negotiations and discussions are being undertaken with the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities. ANSWER.PARA: It is true to say that all three levels of government do have a role, and have accepted that role over a long period. No State government has yet made any long term commitment of that kind to road funding. The Commonwealth believes its commitment to be significant in the light of the overriding need to limit public sector spending in order to control inflation. Moreover, in recent times, since 1976, the Commonwealth has provided substantially increased general revenue assistance to State and local government. This has substantially enhanced the capacity of local government, in accordance with its own priorities, to increase expenditure on those parts of the road system for which State governments and local authorities are primarily responsible. The Commonwealth Government is demonstrating clearly its approach from the national point of view and realising its priorities in this particular area. It encourages governments in the other spheres to take their priorities seriously also and to ensure the development and maintenance of a road system that is of adequate quality and, in fact, meets the projected traffic demands of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was asked to clarify the question of whether tax had been taken into consideration in the West German study of brown and black coal in Australia and in the reports that had been prepared. The first is the economic rate of return and the second the financial rate of return. The economic rate of return, according to the German companies, is intended to reflect the return on the project from the point of view of the nation as a whole. It is based on exclusion of all taxes and import duty which are argued to be transfer payments which in no way diminish the national economic benefit of the project.

ANSWER.PARA: The financial rate of return, on the other hand, is intended to reflect the real after tax return on the project which will be the basis for any commercial development by the private sector and which includes the consideration of taxation and import duty. The main results of the two analyses are summarised for the three plants as follows. The economic DCFROR in New South Wales is 16.6 per cent, in Queensland 17.6 per cent and in Victoria 21.4 per cent. The financial DCFROR in New South Wales is 4.4 per cent, in Queensland 4.6 per cent and in Victoria 7.3 per cent. The Press statement attachments referred specifically to the real after tax DCFROR in the range 4.4 per cent to 7.3 per cent which, while promising to the extent that they appeared to provide a worthwhile basis for further co-operation between Australia and the Federal Republic of Germany, are not in themselves sufficient to justify commercial development. A considerable lift in societies' funds intake in recent months and a restoration of their liquidity position have improved their prospects for achieving an increase in lending throughout the current financial year. In fact, societies in some States are now taking steps to attract borrowers to take up the funds available.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite the effects of the strong competition for household savings on lending institutions, the Government's firm objective is to see an adequate availability of housing finance to credit-worthy borrowers. In 1980-81 a strong lending performance by savings and trading banks cushioned, to a large extent, the decline in lending by permanent building societies. This fall in lending by societies reflects, in part, unrealistic ceilings imposed by some State governments on interest rates paid to investors.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Walsh proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The crippling burden placed on Australian families by the record taxes and interest rates of the Fraser Government.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by sessional order having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —'Interest rates will fall by 2 per cent over the coming year. It is a target that can and will be met'. So asserted the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) in November 1977. At the time he asserted that, interest rates generally-it is not possible to quote a specific figure because there are variations in the rate of interest on borrowings for various purposes between States and between different institutions-were around 10 per cent. Far from falling by 2 per cent as the Prime Minister had promised-'it is a target that can and will be met', he said-interest rates in fact have risen from the general level of 10 per cent prevailing at that time to 13 per cent and 14 per cent today. The effect of an increase in interest rates from 10 per cent to 14 per cent for somebody with a $30,000 housing loan repayable over 30 years is to increase the monthly payments from $265 to $357. That is an increase of $92 a month. Some people have avoided an increase of as much as 4 per cent and have got away with an increase of 3 per cent. For them the figure is somewhat lower-in the vicinity of $70 a month. But everyone with a housing loan of that magnitude on those terms has had his weekly repayments increased by around $20. One million Australians have housing loans of that type. They are squeezed. The effects have not stopped there. No family with an income significantly below average weekly earnings can obtain a loan. At current interest rates and required levels of repayment families in that category are excluded from the home purchase market unless they already have very substantial liquid assets. This, of course, has macro-economic ramifications which are beginning to show in a significant decline in approvals for finance for residential building and for commencements.

SPEECH.PARA: It is true that one very small group does still secure loans and interest rates of less than 10 per cent; indeed, at less than the 10 per cent minus 2 per cent which the Prime Minister promised four years ago. For example, the Prime Minister's wife and her relatives were the recipients, and are still the recipients, of a $50,000 loan at an interest rate of 4 1/2 per cent, granted under murky if not actually illegal circumstances by the Government of Victoria four years ago. Due to the diligence and industry of Senator McLaren-we are indebted to him for this-we have information that Mr Anthony secured a loan of $17,964, which was 95 per cent of the value of the property he was buying, at an interest rate of 4 3/4 per cent repayable over 45 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —For a deposit of $36.

—As Senator Sibraa reminds me, the deposit was $36. For what is rental purchase of that house, Mr Anthony pays $80 a month. I am reliably informed that the commercial rent for a house of that type is in the vicinity of $100 a week. Mr Anthony's rental purchase payments are $80 a month. The $80 he pays is less than the increase in charges over the last three years for ordinary people. Also, Mr Anthony got a $320 a week pay rise this year.

SPEECH.PARA: There is yet another remarkable aspect of this story. The loan which Mr Anthony was granted, and still has, was granted in 1964 by ministerial allocation-that is a technical term-by the then Minister for the Interior, who was Mr Anthony. It is a clear case of the Country Party helping itself. Mr Nixon has a loan of $30,352. He was advanced 95 per cent of the value of the property he bought at an interest rate of 6 1/4 per cent, again over 45 years. Because of the much higher value of the property and the somewhat higher interest rates, his monthly repayment-remember that it is rental purchase-is $168 a month; something less than half of what the typical Australian family pays for a loan of the same size. Yet the typical Australian family has an income of about 25 per cent of Mr Nixon's. That loan, too, was approved by ministerial allocation, in 1970, by the Minister for the Interior who was, would you believe, Peter Nixon. The Country Party helps itself again. It is true that at that time the rates of interest charged were not greatly below commercial rates and that other people, including politicians, also borrowed at around that time. However, I stress that all serving politicians other than those mentioned paid back their loans long ago. Only these two people have kept them. They are bludging on their fellow taxpayers. Mr Anthony still owes 84 per cent of his original debt; Mr Nixon owes 94 per cent of the original loan. They are living in houses part time under rental purchase arrangements for a tiny fraction of normal current commercial rent for houses of that calibre.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't pay tax on the subsidy, either.

—And they do not pay tax on the subsidy. The Prime Minister should order them to return the properties to the taxpayers from whom they have filched, or at the very least order them to pay off the outstanding balance instead of continuing to bludge on their fellow taxpayers with interest rates significantly less than half prevailing commercial rates. Mr Sinclair, demonstrating again the propensity of the Country Party to hang together in times of trouble-these days it is always in trouble-has defended the actions of his fellow Ministers with these words:

SPEECH.PARA: Doug Anthony, Peter Nixon and I--
Mr Sinclair also received a loan, which he has repaid-
received no different terms to those available to every other Canberra citizen.

Doug Anthony, Peter Nixon and Ian Sinclair are not and never were Canberra citizens. They exploited provisions made available to Canberra citizens and authorised loans for themselves, two of which are still outstanding. Only a tiny fraction of the principal has been repaid on each loan. They, themselves, authorised the loans that they still have. By ministerial allocation, the Country Party helps itself. The Prime Minister has refused to provide a guarantee that these same two or other Ministers are not simultaneously receiving almost 24 per cent interest from the Commonwealth on money that they have lodged with the Commonwealth, at the same time evading and avoiding their just taxation liabilities. A near-hysterical Country Party leader last Sunday claimed that these and other factual revelations constituted personal smears by what he called 'toads'. I understand he was almost frothing at the mouth at the time he made those allegations. His deputy leader attacked the journalists who published such facts. The wife of the closet Country Party Prime Minister, when the question of the loan to her and her relatives was raised, said that anyone who would raise such a question was lower than a snake's duodenum.

What this bunyip mafia is really asserting is its divine right to plunge its collective fist into the public till whenever it feels inclined. When these people are caught, they attack those who have blown the whistle on them. They tried the same tactics when the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations report on the Australian Dairy Corporation was tabled. It backfired on them very badly, I am pleased to report, and this will too. When there is a trail of scandal such as that left behind by the Country Party, left by this bunyip mafia, it is no surprise that someone discovers it. Indeed, a responsible Opposition would be negligent or worse if it failed to discover such a trail of scandal and to draw it to the attention of the public. Of course journalists who failed to publish revealed facts would be equally negligent. There may have been a sinister implication in Mr Anthony's expressions of admiration last week for the regime in Chile. In Chile, of course, journalists would not be allowed to publish that sort of information. One wonders whether the Country Party in its simultaneous expression of admiration for the Chilean regime and vilification of Australian journalists thought that adoption of some Chilean methods might be appropriate in Australia.

Mr Fraser, Mr Anthony, Mr Sinclair and Mr Nixon, almost the entire Cabinet, the Ministry and even the back bench of this Government are out of touch with reality and out of touch with the people. They should have been where I was last weekend talking to residents of a far northern beach suburb of Perth called Heathridge. It comprises about 250 houses which were occupied in quite a short time around two and a half years ago. Twenty-eight of those 250 houses are on the market because the occupiers can no longer maintain the payments to which they are committed and which have increased by around $80 a month or $20 a week because of the record interest rates of this Government. What is happening in Heathridge is being repeated in hundreds of similar areas right around Australia. That will sweep this Government from office whenever the next election is held.

Those not alienated by interest rates will be alienated by record taxation. The Prime Minister's promises on taxation are revealed as being as phoney as his promise on interest rates. In the heady days of 1975 and even in 1977 he used to say: 'We will end the great tax rip-off'. He promised to index the taxation scales every year to end what he used to call the secret tax of inflation. We do not hear very much about the secret tax of inflation since indexation was finally and completely buried four months ago.

The aggregate of government tax collections is revealed, among other places, in Budget Paper No. 1 at page 273, which shows Budget receipts as a proportion of gross domestic product over the last 10 years. I cite the details for just two of those years. In 1975-76, the year of the last Labor Budget, taxes constituted 25.1 per cent of the GDP. That was a crippling level of taxation, according to Mr Fraser at the time. The estimate for this year, 1981-82, is that as a proportion of GDP taxes will be 27.5 per cent. So that is an increase from 25.1 per cent, which was allegedly an intolerable burden, to 27.5 per cent. They are the aggregate figures. Last year the Government imposed the highest ever levels of income tax. For wage and salary earners it is estimated that those record levels will rise another 22 per cent this year. In addition there is a crude oil levy that will yield about $3.5 billion a year. The Government has now widened and deepened indirect taxes with the notorious set of Bills which will raise an estimated $900m in a full year. In the same Budget that increased wage and salary earners' taxes by 22 per cent these notorious sales tax Bills were introduced in spite of the promise given by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) on 24 November last year, on one of many other occasions, when he said:
. . . if there was an increase in indirect tax, it would be in the context of a reduction in personal tax.

In fact this massive increase in indirect tax-a 38 per cent increase in sales tax from both broadening and deepening sales tax-accompanied a 22 per cent increase in income tax on wage and salary earners. It is not only the aggregates. Within those aggregates the burden of taxation has been regressively redistributed. I do not have time in this discussion to go through many figures. On 13 October the Sydney Morning Herald published details derived from information supplied by Mr Risstrom which showed that in 1975-76 a family of four on a single income of 85 per cent of average weekly earnings paid 9 per cent of that income in tax. Now the same family pays 16 per cent of its income in tax-up 80 per cent. In 1975-76 a family of four on average weekly earnings with a single income paid 10 per cent of its income in tax. It now pays 18 per cent. That family's tax is also up 80 per cent. These single income families are the very families which this Government purports to be concerned about. All taxpayers with current incomes below $16,500-that is, more than 70 per cent of all taxpayers-paid a higher proportion of their income in tax in 1980-81 than they did in 1975-76. Those wage earners will pay 22 per cent more this year. There is no doubt that within the next 12 months something called tax cuts will be reintroduced. They will not be real tax cuts.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has talked, in conservative terms, of where the money will come from. I would like to address myself to the question of tax avoidance. This is a matter about which this Governments trumpets loudly in the electorate from time to time. What has happened over the last five years is that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Government have made a puzzle of Australia's taxation legislation which makes the Rubik cube seem as simple as a game of snakes and ladders. Time and again the Treasurer has put forward to the Parliament legislation seeking to close off loopholes and to stop schemes, but it is reactive legislation. It is governmental action of the worst kind to combat one of the gravest social problems facing our country. Let us look at the result of the work put in by the Treasurer. He is a man who knows absolutely nothing about weekly shopping, as his economic initiatives indicate.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1976 the number of people involved in tax avoidance schemes has increased by more than 1,200 per cent. The conservative estimate of the cost of tax avoidance is $1,000m a year. I tend to think that Professor Russell Mathews of the Australian National University was much closer to the mark when he said a year ago that in the 1978-79 financial year tax avoidance had cost the community $2,715m. Quite recently we had the Commissioner of Taxation lending his weight to the allegation that the problem is increasing exponentially. That someone such as the amoral and despicable Peter Clyne, a real enemy of the Australian system, can still operate, make profits and continue to flout the tax laws is perhaps the greatest indictment of this Government's mealy-mouthed, wishy-washy and ultimately futile approach to dealing with tax avoidance. Any tax laws which leave room for the rotund Mr Clyne to barge his way through are clearly unacceptable and not worth the time and effort put into their drafting.

As has been said many times in the past, because of this Government's lack of any real action on tax avoidance the paying of income tax by the wealthy in this community has become a voluntary action. Let us look at two instances that have been brought forward in recent weeks. About a month ago before a Senate Estimates committee the Taxation Office admitted in a letter to the committee that the reduction of manpower in the Taxation Office will result in an estimated revenue loss this year of $46.8m. At the same time, because of the rigid application of a 3 per cent across the board cut in staff ceilings, the Taxation Office has lost 179 officers. The consequence of the Government's actions has been to save $1.5m by way of salaries. Because of that it will accrue a net loss to revenue of $45.3m. That is one Government action which is totally short sighted and which gives lie to the fact that the Government and the Treasurer are concerned about tax avoidance.

I now turn to the report of the Commissioner of Taxation which was tabled in the Parliament on 28 October. The Commissioner identified 11,253 tax avoiders in the financial year 1978-79. For the year 1979-80 he identified 17,200 tax avoiders. For the year 1980-81 he identified 22,366 participants in tax avoidance schemes, involving revenue losses of $973m-or almost $43,500 lost tax per tax avoider. When one compares these figures with the figures relating to tax avoidance in 1975-76, which was the last year of the Whitlam Labor Government, one will find that there has been a massive explosion of tax avoidance under this Government. It goes through the actions but is not prepared to take firm and effective action to bring about results in this vital area.

A very small number of people in our community can benefit from tax avoidance schemes. For 80 per cent of Australians there is no choice. Tax is, for them, a financial imperative which cannot be avoided. What has the Government done to make life more easy for these people? Absolutely nothing. Wage and salary earners, who have seen their incomes rise by 98 per cent since 1975-76, have seen the amount of taxation that they pay increase by 146 per cent. If this Government had done something about tax avoidance in this period the massive tax burden would not be as great as it is now.

The Minister, in her attack on Senator Walsh and in her neglect to discuss the Government position on taxation, has passed over quite a number of very important facts which I would now like to put on the record. The Minister invited statistics. I now provide them. During the term of the Labor Government total Commonwealth tax receipts as a proportion of gross domestic product averaged 22.5 per cent. During the six years of the Fraser Government the average has been 24.1 per cent. In our last year of government the figure stood at 23.3 per cent. In this Budget year it stands at 25.5 per cent. That is an all time record high.

Let us look at net pay-as-you-earn tax receipts as a proportion of total tax revenue. These are the tax receipts which come out of the pockets of wage and salary earners. In our last year of government, 1975-76, that proportion stood at 41.7 per cent. Under the Fraser Government it is expected to be 45.7 per cent in this financial year. Once again that is an Australian record high. If one compares that with company tax receipts as a proportion of total Commonwealth tax receipts, very quickly one will see who is bearing the burden of the Government's economic policies. One will see that under the Labor Government company tax receipts were 16.6 per cent of total Commonwealth receipts. Under the present Government they have gone down to just under 14 per cent. The facts are there. They can be looked at. They are on the public record. I will not continue with the figures in view of the time limit, but I will raise them in future debate.

At a time when wage and salary earners are paying massive increases in taxation, tax collections from the private sector and the wealthy have declined. In fact, they have declined by more than $6,000m. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle may very well ask where our funding will come from. Let us look at the record of this Government. The shift of money out of the pockets of wage and salary earners brought about by this Government has been massive, as I have shown. More importantly, by shifting the target of its funding, as the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Mr Lionel Bowen, has said, it has brought about a massive shift in government funding from the community sector to private enterprise and to multinational investment. In the three or four minutes which are available to me I wish to return quickly to an area of tax avoidance which this Government, once again, refuses to attack; that is, the area of transfer pricing. I refer to the method by which goods are sold to a subsidiary of a transnational corporation which is operating in a tax haven. A price structure is developed to transfer prices and profits. What happens under these transactions is that the profits incurred by a company are pushed off-shore. As a consequence, company profits and taxation on them are assessed in havens overseas.

In an important High Court ruling in August 1980 the eminent Mr Justice Lionel Murphy went straight to the heart of the matter. It was the case of the Commonwealth Commissioner of Taxation v. the Commonwealth Aluminium Corporation Ltd. The court determined that the corporation was in fact a foreign owned corporation, owned by Comalco. Mr Justice Murphy had this to say about the system under which the transfer pricing operated:

During the tax years in question, a substantial part of the taxpayers' product, bauxite, was shipped directly to Japan to two Japanese companies . . . although it had been sold to a Hong Kong company, Comalco Bauxite (H.K.) Ltd, 52 per cent of which is owned by Comalco and 48 per cent equally of the two Japanese companies. The Hong Kong company was intended to and did relatively little except for book entries. There was no physical delivery to it. It simply purchased the bauxite from the taxpayer, for example at 33 shillings per ton, and told it to the Japanese at 40 shillings per ton. The taxpayer acted on Comalco's directions and it is very relevant to the question of control that it sold to a company controlled by Comalco which was ultimately owned by those whom the Commissioner claims control the taxpayers.

What happened in this case was that one arm of a company sold to another arm in another country and evaded taxation. That is how transfer pricing operates and it goes on every day with a resultant loss in revenue of millions and millions of dollars. The Government continues to ignore this loss of revenue. It does nothing about it. If Senator Guilfoyle invites policies, I indicate at this stage that the Labor Party does have a policy in respect of this. I close at this stage but in doing so address myself to the point made earlier. The Government is responsible for crippling high rates of interest rates and taxation. It has an alternative, but has not chosen to adopt it. I believe that in the 15 minutes available to me I have shown one particular area in which the Government can act to decrease the burden on wage and salary earners in this country.

When the demagogues of the labour movement, or of the building society movement, or the populists on both sides of politics, begin shouting for assistance to mortgage borrowers and for lower interest rates they should reflect on what they are asking for.
