SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to set out in a clear and precise form the rights and duties of citizens and members of the Australian Federal Police in relation to the investigation of offences against laws of the Commonwealth and the Australian Capital Territory. At the same time, the Bill seeks to establish a proper balance between the community's need for effective law enforcement and the need to preserve and respect basic human rights and freedoms. It will complement the provisions of the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 recently enacted by Parliament. In March 1977, Attorney-General Ellicott introduced a like measure, the Criminal Investigation Bill 1977, which implemented, broadly speaking, the report of the Law Reform Commission on this subject. In respect of the limited difference between the majority and minority reports, the Bill followed the minority report. To enable the public and interested bodies, to study adequately the legislation, the Bill lay on the table until the end of 1977, when it lapsed with the dissolution of Parliament.

Few Bills have attracted more public comment and attention than the Criminal Investigation Bill 1977. Comments and criticisms were received from a very wide cross-section of the community and from many public bodies and professional associations, including the Law Council and police associations. After careful consideration of these comments and criticisms, the Government decided that the Bill should be comprehensively reviewed to determine to what extent the criticisms could be met, without impairing the essential purposes of the Bill. One particular object of the review was to simplify the language of the Bill and the procedures provided by it because much criticism had been directed to the complexity of the Bill in those respects.

My Department accordingly conducted a thorough review of the 1977 Bill in conjunction with other interested departments and the Australian Federal Police. In the course of this review, scientific, legal and other experts were consulted and the practical application of the legislation was taken into account. The difficulties seen by the police forces in the 1977 Bill were examined in considerable detail. During the review, members of the United Kingdom Royal Commission on Criminal Procedure visited Australia to look into Australian developments in the regulation of criminal investigation. I and officers of my Department involved in this project had a useful exchange of ideas with members of the Commission. As a result of these consultations and the review generally, the Bill was substantially redrafted. The Commissioner, Australian Federal Police Force, has indicated that the Bill, so far as his Force is concerned, is in a workable form. For myself, looking at the Bill from the point of view of preservation of individual rights as well as the need for effective law enforcement, I am satisfied that the Bill is now appropriate for enactment by Parliament.

Quite a number of changes have been made in the Bill from its 1977 form but these changes, I am pleased to say, do not interfere with the major reforms provided for in the 1977 Bill which in turn were based on the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission. The more significant reforms to be effected by the present Bill may be briefly described as follows:
1. A person held in custody will be given a specific right to be assisted by a lawyer.
2. Strict criteria will be laid down for arrest without warrant and the taking of fingerprints will only be permitted for identification purposes.
3. Restrictions will be imposed on the use of force, including firearms, for the purpose of arrests.
4. Safeguarding provisions will be introduced as to the identification of suspects by identification parades and other procedures to ensure that injustices are not thereby committed.

5. Restrictions will be placed on the questioning of Aboriginals except in the presence of 'a prisoner's friend' and on the questioning of persons not fluent in English except in the presence of an interpreter. These provisions are similar to some of the provisions contained in a private member's Bill already introduced into the Senate by Senator Bonner. They are designed to recognise the need for special assistance for Aboriginals when being subjected to interrogation on criminal matters.
6. Rules are laid down as to the recording and admissibility of oral confessions made to police officers.

7. Substantial alterations are made to the system of police bail, including the spelling out of criteria to be applied by the police in making decisions as to the grant or refusal of bail; provision will also be made entitling a person refused bail by the police to appeal immediately to a magistrate, if necessary by telephone.

8. The police will be given the power to require persons to identify themselves where they may be able to assist police in inquiries in relation to an offence and reciprocal power is also to be given to citizens in those circumstances to require the police to identify themselves.

9. General search warrants are to be abolished and specific provision will be made for the granting of search warrants, detailing the situations in which searches may be conducted without warrant and providing for obtaining a warrant over the telephone.

10. In a prosecution for an offence, the onus will be on the prosecution to justify the admission of evidence obtained in contravention of any of the procedures or requirements laid down in the legislation.

At the same time, the Bill substantially simplifies the language of the 1977 Bill and the procedures provided under that measure. For example, the provisions of the 1977 Bill setting out when a person was under restraint gave rise to considerable misunderstandings; it was even thought, for instance, that the Bill created new powers of custody by police officers. In the current Bill the corresponding provision-clause 4-has been replaced by simpler language making clear that persons who would not normally be regarded as in custody are to be treated by the Bill as being in custody for the purpose only of conferring rights on them and corresponding duties on police officers.

One significant departure from the terms of the 1977 Bill is to be found in the provision made in the current Bill, for recording of police interviews with suspects. The 1977 provisions would have required the entire police interview with a suspect to be tape recorded or conducted in the presence of an appropriate witness unless it was in all the circumstances impractical to do so. Further, a police officer recording such an interview would have been required to deliver the record to an authorised custodian who would have been required to furnish on application a transcript of the recording to the person interviewed. The objection seen by the police to this requirement was that, in their experience, action at the beginning of an interview with a suspect to record it openly would, in many cases, cause the suspect to refuse to talk further to the police officer or otherwise assist the police in their inquiries. This is a human reaction but different considerations apply when the interview is further advanced. On the police view, the 1977 Bill would therefore seriously have affected criminal investigation processes. It was also pointed out that an obligation to furnish transcripts of recordings of police interviews would have placed a very heavy and expensive burden on the police force. I must say that these objections could not lightly be dismissed.

One of the more frequent complaints made today in relation to the criminal investigation process concerns cases where there is, for one reason or another, no record of the police interview acknowledge in writing by the defendant and conflicting testimony is given as to oral admissions allegedly made by the defendant to the police. In the jargon, the police are accused of 'verballing' the defendant, that is, falsely attributing oral admissions to him. I would not for a moment wish to be understood as accepting that this in reality occurs with any frequency. However, the allegations are made from time to time and if, with the advance of modern technology, we can evolve procedures to reduce the possibility of these allegations being made, it behoves us to do so.

To this end, the present Bill will provide that, on the trial of indictable offences under the law of the Commonwealth or the Australian Capital Territory, evidence may be given of oral admissions made by the accused to a police officer only if one of three procedures have been followed by the police. The first procedure will require that the entire interview is sound recorded and a copy of the recording is given to the accused. The second procedure will require that a record in writing of the interview has been duly acknowledged in writing by the accused. The third procedure will require that a record in writing is made as soon as practicable after the admission in question and this record is read to the accused, who is afforded the opportunity to comment on the accuracy of the record, this process being sound recorded or conducted in the presence of an appropriate witness. In the event of it being sound recorded, a copy of the recording must be given to the accused. I emphasise that it will be sufficient compliance with the Act if one of these procedures is observed. Which of the procedures should be followed by a police officer in a particular instance will depend on the circumstances of the case including the attitude of the suspect.

Mr Acting Deputy President, the Government believes that these legislative requirements will go a long way to removing disputes that take up so much of the time of the courts as to the terms of oral admissions made by suspects. In explaining this approach, I should like to acknowledge the contribution made to the thinking on this subject by the Queensland Committee of Inquiry into the Enforcement of Criminal Law under the chairmanship of Mr Justice Lucas in its report of April 1977.
Other significant changes from the 1977 Bill include the following:

1. Arrest without warrant. In sub-clause 10 (2) the circumstances in which a police officer may arrest without warrant are extended beyond the 1977 provision to include where the police officer believes on reasonable grounds that the arrest of the person is necessary in order to achieve-
the purpose of preventing the commission of a further offence; or
the purpose of preserving the safety or welfare of the person.

The reasons for the variation are self-evident. In sub-clause (4) a power of arrest is also provided in respect of a person who is escaping, or has escaped from lawful custody. The provisions are also extended to cover State and Northern Territory police officers arresting persons for Commonwealth or Territory offences.

2. Warnings. One of the complaints made in relation to the 1977 Bill was the requirement for what was described as a 'multiplicity of warnings'. The requirements are now simplified. For example, while clause 19 provides for the giving of a warning when a person is in custody, this may be dispensed with if the warning required at the point when the officer made up his mind to charge-clause 20-had been given at or during the interview.

3. Aboriginals. It was considered unnecessary to provide for the attendance of a prisoner's friend during a police interview of an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander where, because of that person's level of education or understanding, he would not be at a disadvantage in comparison with the Australian community generally.

4. Identification. The grounds for taking fingerprints are extended to clause 34 to cover the purposes of establishing who the person is. The operation of the provision is also confined to persons in custody.

In clause 36, on the advice of scientific experts, the requirement in the 1977 Bill that, before permitting a witness to look at persons included in an identification parade, the police should obtain from the witness a written description of the person to be identified has been removed. So also has the requirement that a record of the names and addresses of participants in an identification parade should be provided to the suspect.
5. Search warrants. The changes in substance are:
The requirement for an affidavit has been abolished as all relevant details can be and on present practice are, contained in the information.

The maximum duration of a warrant is extended from seven days to one month. This was because seven days was considered unrealistic. These days warrants may have to be executed in several States or it may be necessary to wait for the occurrence of a particular incident before executing the warrant.

By sub-clause 58 (5) a police officer who, in the course of searching for the thing specified in the warrant, finds another thing that he believes on reasonable grounds to be connected with the offence in respect of which the warrant was granted or another offence and that it is necessary to seize that thing in order to prevent its concealment, loss or destruction is authorised to seize it.

It is made clear that a search warrant may authorise the removal of clothing for forensic examination. As an extra safeguard for these and other searches of a person, the Bill requires that females may be searched only by female officers.

6. Entrapment. The prohibition on entrapment has been extended to a police officer causing another person to induce a person to commit an offence. On the other hand, the exemption has been widened to take into account the necessities of police work.

7. Exclusion of Evidence Rule. Since the Law Reform Commission's Report was published, the High Court in 1978 handed down its decision in the case of Bunning v. Cross which established the law in Australia on exclusion of evidence obtained in contravention of the law. Clause 69 has been altered to reflect the law as laid down in that case.

8. Emergency provisions. In clauses 21, 26, 28 and 29, emergency provisions have been inserted to enable a police officer to take action, for example, before the arrival of a lawyer, where he has reasonable grounds to believe that it is necessary to take such action to prevent danger of loss of life, personal injury or serious damage to property. The reason for the variation is self-evident.

9. Handicapped Persons. A number of provisions have been added to provide procedures to be followed when dealing with physically handicapped suspects. This last change reflects the Government's particular concern in this, the International Year of Disabled Persons, to take account of the special needs of handicapped persons as members of our community and the particular vulnerability of such persons when faced by authorities with whom they may be unable to communicate.

Having regard to Australia's ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights in August 1980, it is particularly apposite to note the extent to which the Bill gives effect to that Covenant. Thus Article 9 of the Covenant provides:

1. Everyone has the right to liberty and security of person. No one shall be subjected to arbitrary arrest or detention. No one shall be deprived of his liberty except on such grounds and in accordance with such procedure as are established by law.
2. Everyone who is arrested shall be informed, at the time of arrest, of the reasons for his arrest and shall be promptly informed of any charges against him.
Article 10 provides:
1. All persons deprived of their liberty shall be treated with humanity and with respect for the inherent dignity of the human person.

Article 14 contains a number of provisions entitling a person, subject to any criminal charge against him, to minimum guarantees in procedures for the determination of that change. They include guarantees:
3. (a) To be informed promptly and in detail in a language which he understands of the nature and cause of the charge against him;
(b) To have adequate time and facilities for the preparation of his defence and to communicate with counsel of his own choosing;
(f) To have the free assistance of an interpreter if he cannot understand or speak the language used in court;
(g) Not to be compelled to testify against himself or to confess guilt;

Other provisions of the international Covenant are clearly relevant to this Bill which can be regarded as a practical step to implement the obligations of the Covenant. It is interesting to note that the Bill represents probably the first attempt by a common law country to state comprehensively the principles applying to criminal investigation, consistently with the requirements of the International Covenant. In a real and practical way this Bill, together with the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981 and the Human Rights Commission Act 1981 demonstrates the concern of the Government with the protection and promotion of the rights of the individual. The Bill exemplifies the government's appreciation that the rights of the individual, to be effective, need to be set out clearly and specifically.

In the view of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police-with which I agree-the Bill also represents the single most significant reform in Australian policing. Its impact on the operations of the Australian Federal Police will be considerable. The Government intends that sufficient time should be available both for detailed consideration of the Bill and to allow the Australian Federal Police to prepare for the many operational and administrative changes this legislation will necessitate.

It is hoped that the legislation will be debated towards the end of the autumn session of the Parliament and I look forward to receiving submissions from honourable senators and members and from all other interested persons and organisations, if possible by mid-January 1982. Mr Deputy President, much time and effort has gone into the review of the 1977 Bill. As a result, the present Bill represents, I believe, a workable and sensible balance between the needs of law enforcement and the preservation of individual rights. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Peter Baume) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
Most of the amendments in the Statute Law (Miscellaneous Amendments) Bill 1981 are ones that would normally be included in a Statute Law Revision Act of the kind passed earlier this year.

Some are designed to correct printing and drafting errors that have been found to exist in a number of Acts. Another provision provides for the repeal of Acts the operation of which is exhausted or which are no longer required. Other provisions make a number of technical or minor amendments.

Other provisions go to matters of substance in varying degrees-as indeed did the Statute Law Revision Act 1981-but they are regarded as suitable, in the interests of legislative expedition, for inclusion in an omnibus measure of this kind.

The provisions of the present Bill that deal with the matters of statute law revision in the narrowest sense do not call for particular comment. I propose to explain in some detail the nature and effect of the other provisions, taking them in the order in which they appear in the Bill.
Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976

The principal purpose of the proposed amendments to the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976 is to remove a constraint which prevented, even with the Minister's approval, councils and associations incorporated under the Act from selling, mortgaging or otherwise disposing of their assets to non-Aboriginal bodies or individuals.

Although originally included in the Act to protect land provided for Aboriginals by the Commonwealth against unwarranted disposal, the constraint has been counterproductive to the social and economic development of Aboriginals.

The consent of the Minister will be required in the situations dealt with by the amendments. I should add that nothing in the amendments would place in jeopardy land held under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.
Australian Capital Territory Evidence (Temporary Provisions) Act 1971

Clause 11 amends the Australian Capital Territory Evidence (Temporary Provisions) Act 1971 so as to allow the provisions of the Evidence Ordinance 1971 of the Territory to be amended or repealed by an ordinance of the Territory.

The Evidence Ordinance 1971 contains comprehensive rules of evidence for civil and criminal proceedings in the Australian Capital Territory. The Ordinance was disallowed by the Senate in 1971 but its provisions were kept in force by the Act because the disallowance had left the Territory without adequate evidence laws for criminal trials.

However, the Act did not provide for any amendment of the provisions of the Ordinance. At present those provisions have the status of an Act and can be amended only by an Act of the Parliament. Moreover, difficulties can arise in the inclusion of desirable evidence provisions in other Territory ordinances because of possible invalidity due to inconsistency with the Evidence Ordinance. The amendment will remedy this situation.

Early in 1972 the then Attorney-General introduced a Bill for an Act to replace the Ordinance but the Bill was referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs for consideration and was not enacted. Following a recommendation of the Committee, the law of evidence applicable in proceedings in Federal and Territory Courts was referred to the Law Reform Commission in 1979 for review and report. The Commission's report is not expected for some time. The amendment proposed by the Bill is an interim measure only, pending the report of the Law Reform Commission.
Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933
Part VI of the Bill makes four amendments to the Australian Capital Territory Supreme Court Act 1933.

Clause 14 amends section 10 of the Act to enable a new judge of the Court to take the oaths or affirmations of allegiance and of office before another judge of the Court, a justice of the High Court or a judge of the Federal Court of Australia. This amendment will remove the need for the Governor-General to appoint, each time a new judge is appointed, a person before whom the judge may take the oaths or affirmations.

Clause 15 inserts a new provision dealing with the delivery of reserved judgments. The new provision will enable reserved judgments of the Court constituted by three or more judges to be delivered by any one of them, thereby removing the need to reassemble the whole of the Court merely for the purposes of delivery of the judgment.

Clause 16 deals with prosecution of indictable offences triable before the Supreme Court. Section 53 of the Supreme Court Act now provides for such offences to be prosecuted by information in the name of the Attorney-General or such other person as the Governor-General appoints in that behalf. The amendment to be made by clause 16 will remove the need for an appointment to be made by the Governor-General and enable an appointment to be made by the Attorney-General by instrument in writing.

Clause 17 inserts a new section 53A which provides that, unless good cause is shown to the contrary, upon application, the Court is to include, in any judgment for a pecuniary amount, an amount in respect of interest. The amount of interest is to be within the discretion of the Court and the interest is to be calculated, as the Court thinks fit, on the whole or any part of the money for the whole or any part of the period between the date the cause of action arose and the date of judgment. A lump sum may be ordered in lieu of such interest.
Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act 1978

Part VII of the Bill provides for certain amendments to the Australian Overseas Projects Corporation Act 1978 to rectify a number of legislative deficiencies which have become apparent in the course of the Corporation's operations.
The amendments embrace four particular areas of concern and propose-
(i) an expanded definition of 'development project' as contained in the Act to include projects concerned solely with the supply of services.
(ii) the inclusion of a provision to enable the Corporation to engage directly in negotiations on overseas projects with overseas clients at the request of the Australian Government.
(iii) the inclusion of a provision to enable the Corporation under certain circumstances to act at the request of an authority of the Commonwealth or a State Government.

(iv) the replacement of the maximum contingent liability concept in the Act which has proved difficult to define precisely in terms of the Corporation's activities with the concept of assessed net commercial risk.
The effect of implementing these amendments will be to enable the Corporation to operate more effectively and in line with the original objectives of the legislation.
Bankruptcy Act 1966

The South Australian Government has asked that bankruptcy matters in that State should be taken over by the Federal Court of Australia. At present bankruptcy matters there are heard before the State Court of Insolvency, in which a judge of the South Australian District and Criminal Courts sits part-time. The purpose of clauses 28 to 30 of the Bill is to transfer all matters pending before the State Court of Insolvency into the Federal Court from a date to be proclaimed. At the same time, it is convenient to remove the bankruptcy jurisdiction presently vested in the Victorian Court of Insolvency, which has not sat for some years. The Supreme Courts in those two States will be invested with jurisdiction in bankruptcy, bringing them into line with the Supreme Courts in the other States. In practice, however, all bankruptcy matters in Victoria and South Australia will be dealt with by the Federal Court.
Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918

In a statement to Parliament on 7 May 1981 the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs foreshadowed amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act in relation to requirements to enrol, to vote and to nominate as a candidate for election to Parliament. Following close consultations with State governments, it has been determined that Australian citizenship is the appropriate basis for the franchise and for nomination as a candidate for election to Parliament. The Government considers that migrants, irrespective of their country of origin, should be treated equally in relation to these matters.
Part IX of the Bill gives effect to these decisions. It is to come into operation on a day to be proclaimed.

In regard to the requirements to enrol and to vote, the changes to legislation will not of themselves confer a right to vote upon any further categories of people. The only group of migrants affected by the changes will be British subjects who are not Australian citizens and who have not enrolled before the coming into operation of the legislation. In future, only Australian citizens will be entitled to enrol. I should emphasise, however, that the changes will not disenfranchise anyone. Compulsory voting will continue for all those who are on the roll at the date of commencement of the legislation. Not only will their rights be preserved; they will be obliged to maintain their enrolments.
From date of commencement of the new provisions, membership of the Australian Parliament will be restricted to Australian citizens.

The introduction of these changes will constitute a further milestone in the social and political development of Australia. The changes reflect the Government's commitment to enhancing the value and status of Australian citizenship and to the consistent and non-discriminatory treatment of all migrant groups. Most States have already agreed to introduce similar legislation. It is desirable that there be a uniform commencement date across Australia for the new arrangements and it has been agreed in principle that this should be early in 1982. The actual date will be determined in conjunction with State governments.
Designs Amendment Act 1981

Part X of the Bill amends the Designs Amendment Act 1981. Clause 39 operates to insert a definition of 'legal personal representative' into the Designs Act 1906, the effect of which is to remove the requirement for the executor or administrator of the estate of the deceased owner of or applicant for a design registration to obtain in the Australian Capital Territory-or elsewhere in Australia-a resealing to the grant of probate or of the letters of administration.

Clause 40 first makes it clear that a separate application for design registration is to be made in respect of each article-or set of articles-for which the owner seeks design protection, and secondly sets limitations on the type of amendments which may be made to an application for design registration. Both these provisions embody the long-accepted interpretation of the Designs Act 1906.

Clause 41 amends the provisions allowing restoration of lapsed design registrations. Under the procedure established by the Designs Amendment Act 1981, a design registration is in force for one year from registration, and can be extended, on request made in due time, for three further periods expiring 6, 11 and 16 years after the date on which the application for registration was lodged. If the owner fails to meet the deadline for requesting the second or third extensions the registrations can nevertheless be restored on late application. This is not possible if the deadline for requesting the first extension is not met, but this situation is now remedied by the amendments in clause 41.

The amendment in clause 42 specifically provides that the legal personal representative of the deceased owner of a design may be registered as owner; while clause 43 enables the making of regulations requiring persons to furnish statutory declarations in relation to proceedings under the Designs Act 1906.
Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 and Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980

Part XIII of the Bill revises section 92 of the Minerals (Submerged Lands) Act 1981 to take account of the fact that the Principal Act, which is not yet in operation, provides for imprisonment for a number of offences under the Act.

The effect of the amendment is to provide that such offences shall be indictable offences, and thus triable by jury, unless the defendant and the prosecutor consent to prosecution in a court of summary jurisdiction and the court is satisfied that this is appropriate. The maximum penalty a court of summary jurisdiction may impose is imprisonment for a term not exceeding 2 years or a fine not exceeding $10,000 or both.

Part XVII of the Bill makes a similar amendment for similar reasons to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Amendment Act 1980 concerning prosecution of offences under section 132 of the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. The amendment has the effect of inserting a new section 132 in the 1967 Act, which is to come into effect when the 1980 Act comes into operation.
National Labour Consultative Council Act 1977 and Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975

In September 1981 the Council of Australian Government Employee Organisations (CAGEO) merged with the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and the former body ceased to exist. The amendments in Part XV of the Bill provide for the abolition of CAGEO representation on the National Labour Consultative Council, established under the National Labour Consultative Council Act 1977. Provision is also made by Part XVIII of the Bill for the abolition of CAGEO representation on the Australian Council for Union Training, and on each of the State Councils for Union Training, established under the Trade Union Training Authority Act 1975.

At the same time, the amendments increase by one the number of persons representing the ACTU on the National Labour Consultative Council. They also increase by one the number of ACTU representatives on the Australian Council for Union Training and the number of State Trades and Labour Council (TLC) representatives on the respective State Councils for Union Training. The TLC's are State branches of the ACTU.
Patents Act 1952

The amendments in Schedule 1 of the Bill include amendments of the Patents Act 1952 following from Australian membership of the Patent Cooperation Treaty. The Treaty provides for regulations to be made to prescribe matters of form, times, procedures and fees in relation to matters under the Treaty. Since Australian accession to the Treaty, the regulations made under the Treaty have been amended and further frequent amendment is expected in the early stages of its implementation. To give effect to these amendments it is necessary that the Australian legislation be amended as the Treaty is a Schedule to the Patents Act 1952.

The amendments in the Bill enable effect to be given to amendments to the Regulations made under the Treaty by modifying the definition of 'Treaty' in section 58A of the Patents Act to include the Treaty regulations as amended, subject to the amendments being declared in the Patents regulations. The clause then empowers the Patents regulations to make such declarations. The Schedule of the Bill also amends sub-section 58C (7) of the Patents Act 1952. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

The speech read as follows-

The main purpose of this Bill is to authorise the payment of interest-free non-repayable capital grants totalling $435.75m to the States in 1981-82. This amount represents the grant component of the Loan Council program for State governments in 1981-82 and is one-third of the total program of $1,307.25m agreed at the June 1981 Loan Council meeting.

The Bill also provides for the payment of capital grants in the first six months of 1982-83 up to an amount equal to one-half of the 1981-82 amount, pending passage of legislation to authorise grants in 1982-83.
In keeping with past practice, payments authorised under this Bill may be made from the Consolidated Revenue Fund or from the Loan Fund, and appropriate borrowing authority is included.

These proposed grants represent a continuation of arrangements initiated by the Liberal-Country Party Government in June 1970, which provide that a proportion of the State governments' Loan Council program should take the form of interest-free non-repayable grants instead of what would otherwise be interest-free bearing borrowings by the States.

The effect of the grants is to relieve the States of debt charges-that is, interest payments and sinking fund contributions-which they would otherwise have to pay, and the grants accordingly have a substantial beneficial effect on the States' financial positions.

The grants were introduced to help States finance works such as schools, and other capital works from which debt charges are not normally recovered, The States are, however, entirely free to apply these grants as they choose.
I turn now to the general context in which this Bill is being introduced.

As I have mentioned, the grants which are the subject of this Bill comprise one-third of the States' Loan Council borrowing programs in 1981-82. The Loan Council, at its June 1981 meeting, approved a State governments' program of $1,307.25m for 1981-82, of which two-thirds-$871.5m-comprise borrowings and one-third-$435.75m-is to be provided as capital grants to the States. These amounts are the same as approved in 1980-81.

It is misleading, however, to consider the States' Loan Council borrowings in isolation. As with all forms of funds made available to the States, a direct comparison with last year can only be made in the overall context, including total Commonwealth Budget funds provided to the States and borrowings by State authorities.

Funds to the States from the Commonwealth Budget are estimated to total $12.791m in 1981-82, an increase of 8.5 per cent. This represents nearly one-third of estimated Commonwealth Budget outlays this year. Payments to or for the States in addition to the general purpose capital funds and borrowings are expected to increase by 9.6 per cent to $11,484m in 1981-82. All but $4,477m of this involves general purpose funds which may, of course, be spent by the States however they see fit, including on capital works projects.

Moreover, the arrangements this year see a considerable reduction in the relative importance of specific purpose payments, so much so that overall Commonwealth general purpose payments to the States-payments which can be allocated by the States themselves between recurrent and capital expenditure-are estimated to increase by 28 per cent.

At its June 1981 meeting, the Loan Council also approved an increase in the larger state semi-government authorities' borrowing programs of 11.2 per cent to $2,098.3m for 1981-82, which includes infrastructure borrowings for such authorities of $806.7m.

The decisions of the June 1981 Loan Council meeting on public sector borrowings must finally be seen against the background of re-emerging inflationary pressures-pressures which if allowed to grow unchecked could quickly undermine the current recovery and threaten further development that is in the pipeline.

In summary, the package of funds to the States in 1981-82, including the Loan Council borrowing programs, has been carefully designed both within the constraints of the Commonwealth's continuing policy of responsible restraint on public sector spending and with a view to giving the States further flexibility in determining their own priorities.
This Bill is an important measure in these overall arrangements for Commonwealth Assistance to the States. I commend it to honourable senators.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 November, on motion by Senator Walsh:
That the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1981 No. 302 and made under the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Act 1976, be disallowed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Australian Democrats are not prepared to support Senator Walsh's motion to disallow the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Regulations amendment, basically because we believe that the Income Equalization Deposits Scheme works essentially to help small farmers. Those small farmers have a very difficult row to hoe and income equalisation deposits do in fact help them to even out their income. We have looked at the figures and they show that 75 per cent of the deposits made by farmers under the Scheme average only $6,192 and, in fact, that only 51 people have made deposits in excess of $100,000. If the Scheme is being used as an income tax dodge by the high income farmers-there are not very many of them, as the figures amply demonstrate-that is to be regretted. It would be a matter of some concern to us if the Scheme in the future were to be used for that purpose to any greater degree. However, at the moment, the bulk of the evidence suggests that IEDs are being used by most farmers in the manner in which they were intended to be used; that is, to average the incomes of a group of people whose incomes fluctuate considerably. That is the reason the Scheme was devised and, as far as we can see on the evidence of the figures as we have dissected them, that is essentially what the Scheme is being used for.

SPEECH.PARA: The Scheme does have the potential to be used as a tax dodge, we agree. So far that has not happened. That essentially is the reason for the Democrats being unable to support Senator Walsh's motion. However, we as a party do believe that a register of pecuniary interests for all parliamentarians ought to be set up and that all members and senators ought to declare their financial interests. Only such a register could allay the fears of responsible people. Justice should not only be done but also be seen to be done. For those reasons, we do not support Senator Walsh's motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am disappointed that even though I have sent two sets of circulars to the Australian Democrats in an attempt to educate them on the matter of the disallowance of the Loan (Income Equalization Deposits) Regulations amendment, they have been conned by the spurious arguments of the National Farmers Federation. Senator Siddons admitted that the Democrats have seen that there is considerable potential for the Income Equalisation Deposits Scheme to be used as a tax haven. In failing to support this motion the Democrats will throw away the only weapon which the Senate has to enforce the sorts of reforms that are needed in this Scheme. Those reforms are basically: Firstly, not to pay interest on the tax deferred component of the deposits; secondly, to tighten up the provisions regarding the timing of deposits and withdrawals and the interaction between the timing of deposits and withdrawals and the effect on provisional tax; and, thirdly, to clean up the scandalous mess of the income tax averaging provisions made in 1978 by this Government because of stupid pre-election promises which came straight off the top of the head of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) prior to the 1977 general election.

SPEECH.PARA: Even the National Farmers Federation admits that this is an area of taxation law which needs to be cleaned up. In failing to support this motion the Democrats will throw away the only weapon which the Senate has to enforce some sort of reform on this Government. As I said, the Democrats have been conned by the spurious arguments of the National Farmers Federation-arguments which have been abundant on this issue. I notice that the Federation has not replied to my latest riposte. I do not believe it will. I challenge it to debate the issue publicly in a large forum. The Democrats have fallen for the line that this is a Scheme which helps small farmers. I point out that there are in total only 12,000 deposits from 200,000-odd eligible taxpayers.

My first point is that only somewhat less than 6 per cent of eligible taxpayers are using the Scheme at all. One would have to be incredibly naive to believe that the depositors were all small farmers. Secondly, I refer to the National Farmers Federation's typically spurious manipulation of figures. Senator Siddons referred to figures indicating that 75 per cent of depositors had average deposits of only $6,500, I think it was. While there is probably some correlation between the size of the deposit and taxable income, there is no necessary correlation between the two factors. The fact that somebody has a relatively small deposit proves nothing about the level of that person's income. It is probable that there is a correlation, of course-obviously, somebody who has a very large deposit has a very high income-but there is no one to one correlation between the size of the deposit and the size of the income.

Another way in which the Democrats have been conned by the National Farmers Federation was in the emphasis placed on the number of depositors instead of the amount of money. In fact, 54 per cent of the money which was deposited last financial year-I emphasise, of the money, not of the number of depositors-was in amounts in excess of $20,000. Most of the money that has been paid into that account in the last year came from individuals who paid in individual deposits in excess of $20,000. Those depositors are not likely to be small farmers. It is not the small farmers who are reaping the benefits of this Scheme. As for the National Farmers Federation's humbuggery about their concern for the small farmers, anyone who was concerned about small farmers in respect of this Scheme would be moving to ensure that a higher rate of interest was paid on the deposit net of tax than would otherwise be payable. The Democrats, in adopting the attitude they have, have denied themselves the only means of effectively bringing pressure to bear on this Government to reform this rort.

The final point I make in answer to the arguments of the National Farmers Federation, is that, of course, this rort has not been operating for very long in the way in which it is operating now. The effects of last year's increase in interest rates, up to a maximum effective rate of 17 1/2 per cent, have not yet flowed through into the statistics which are available. To some extent they will show up this year. But the full effects of the rort which this Government has introduced, of this tax haven which this Government has engineered and constructed and which the Democrats now seek to protect, will not become available in official statistics for another two years. I invite honourable senators to record what I say, to mark it down against me if they like: If the Government is actually serious, if it effectively cracks down on other means of tax avoidance, I forecast that there will be a very substantial increase in the use of this tax haven for as long as the provisions, post-Statutory Rule 302, are allowed to prevail. Let us think about the effects of that on the small farmers. I return to Mr Geoff Miller's statement at Agro '79 in Perth in March 1979. He said:
Farmers should aim at achieving tax equity with other people in the community, but not tax concessions not shared with others. Tax concessions result in excessive entry into agriculture--
Have the Australian Democrats grasped the implication of that?

for the specific purpose of receiving the economic reward associated with the concession. Rural land values and the costs of other limited resources, such as livestock and credit, are inflated by this process. Although individuals may benefit, the benefits of tax concessions to rural industries as a whole are likely to be negative.

That statement was made by the former Director of the Bureau of Agricultural Economics. I believe he is now No. 2 in the Department of Primary Industry. I might add that he is a very competent officer. He must be somewhat of a misfit amongst the crowd into which he has recently moved. If rural industries as a whole are not to gain or even be disadvantaged by any provision which makes agriculture a tax haven, which induces excessive competition for the inputs required, the smaller farmers will certainly be greatly disadvantaged. Any measure associated with taxation which confers more than proportionate benefits on high income farmers as against low income farmers reduces the competitive position. It weakens the competitive position of a small farmer vis-a-vis a larger farmer. That is precisely what is done by this tax haven created around income equalisation deposits. The situation was seriously exacerbated by the statutory rule which my motion seeks to deny.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 51 farmers have made deposits exceeding $100,000.

—In a particular year; that is correct. That is my recollection of it. Only 51 farmers have made deposits in excess of $100,000. I am willing to accept that that is correct. But they can make another $100,000 in the following year. Surely the definition of a high income farmer would fall short of somebody who had $100,000 in spare cash to put into an income equalisation deposit. The point I want to make is that the small farmers-about whom the Australian Democrats profess to be concerned and about whom the National Farmers Federation, eyes flowing with crocodile tears, professes to be concerned-are placed in a disadvantageous position vis-a-vis their larger and stronger farming competitors by any measure related to taxation which provides more than proportionate benefits for farmers on higher incomes. I am sorry that the Democrats have not been able to understand that. I have attempted to give them a couple of tutorials on it by way of written papers, but obviously the message has not got through. The Democrats are idly standing by while this Government preserves the tax haven it has created.

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats cannot be taken seriously in the future as a party dedicated to the elimination of tax evasion and avoidance. Indeed the Democrats are collaborators with this Government in preserving tax evasion and avoidance schemes which, I repeat, will disadvantage the very small farmers, the welfare of whom they claim should have a paramount position. Anyone who wants to make sure that the small farmers get a fair deal, this goes particularly for the National Farmers Federation since it chose to use this wholly dishonest argument, would amend these provisions in a way that ensures that the interest-at a higher rate than 9 1/2 per cent; perhaps 12 per cent or 14 per cent-is paid on the deposit net of tax. Senator Bjelke-Petersen and her husband are probably up to their ears in this scheme. As one who has never taken advantage, throughout 25 years of farming, of the various rorts which the Liberal and National Country Party governments have created, I serve notice now, as one who is ideally placed to exploit, as are half the members of the Cabinet which implemented the statutory rule, that if this statutory rule lasts I will exploit it. I will make public statements about the way in which I have exploited it. I will continue to demand that this scandal be cleaned up.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's attempt to defend this rort one week ago was the most pathetic and puerile defence of an indefensible government that I have ever heard in this Senate. She made three points. The first was that John Kerin had said that interest rates ought to be lifted. So have I. So have other people in the Australian Labor Party. This is based on the provision that interest is paid only on that section of the deposit which belongs to the depositor and not, as it is, on that section which belongs to the taxpayers of Australia, which is tax otherwise payable. Her second point was incredible. Obviously she understands nothing about the issue itself. She has not grasped the arithmetic that is involved which, I suppose, is not surprising because normally she knows nothing about anything on which she is asked questions in the Senate. She is the highest paid post box in the world. She refers queries on to other people. She never knows anything and rarely says anything. Obviously she has failed to grasp the fundamental arithmetic relationships in this issue. But if she does not know anything herself, which is not surprising, the Senate is at least entitled to expect that she get advice from people who do. During her speech she said:

The aim of this scheme is to provide a means whereby primary producers can act themselves to smooth out their income flows for taxation purposes by making deposits in high income years and withdrawals in low income years. In this way they can reduce the adverse effects on their taxation liabilities which would result from the interaction of a progressive tax rate scale and fluctuating incomes.

To put that in simpler words, what she was saying was that farmers who use income equalisation deposits to maintain as close as possible to a constant taxable income will avoid taxation penalties which would otherwise apply. Not only is that wrong but also the truth is the complete reverse. Ever since the averaging provisions were amended in 1978 farmers who use income equalisation deposits to smooth out taxable income do not avoid a tax penalty; in fact, they incur one. On the other hand, if they wish to reduce their tax otherwise payable one way to do it is to use income equalisation deposits, not to stabilise taxable income but to destabilise it. Last week I incorporated a table in Hansard. I seek leave to incorporate the same table tonight. The table appears on page 2040 of Hansard of 11 November 1981.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The table shows in detail the way in which a farmer may evade taxation liability by using income equalisation deposits not to stabilise income but to destabilise income. If Senator Guilfoyle did not know that before, did she not look at the table that I presented? Did she not understand it? Does she understand anything? Although it may not surprise the Senate that Senator Guilfoyle has no command of the fundamentals of the area she is supposed to cover, at least we are entitled to expect that her advisers, who I notice are again present in the chamber, can give her better information than to provide the peg upon which the Government hangs most of its argument for retaining these provisions-something which was not only wrong and inaccurate but also the complete reverse of the truth. Farmers do not avoid taxation penalties by using IEDs to smooth out taxable income; they incur taxation penalties if they use them. But if they use IEDs to destabilise taxable income they evade forever the payment of tax which would otherwise be due. On that spurious defence the Government rests its total case, and the Australian Democrats have accepted that case.

SPEECH.PARA: The third point made was the assertion that it was impractical to administer the scheme in the way that I had outlined; that is, that the interest be paid on the deposit net of tax which would otherwise have been payable. That contention also is wrong. It is necessary to introduce certain restrictions and provisions but they are of the type which already apply in regard to the payment of provisional tax. For example, most deposits are lodged in June, July or August and are deductible from taxable income in the year ended 30 June. Taxation returns for that year should, according to the law, be lodged by 31 August, which is 9 to 12 months before the first interest payment is due. In other words, if the conditions of the Income Tax Assessment Act are being strictly observed, for all those deposits made in June, July and August the Australian Taxation Office will have a taxation return in its hands 9 to 12 months before the interest payment is due. It is obviously a very simple matter to calculate the tax deferred component of the deposit and pay the interest accordingly. Returns are not always lodged by 31 August, it is true, and some other arrangements would be necessary to determine the relevant taxable income when interest was due on a deposit lodged in, say, September of any year, but that problem would not be insurmountable.

There are a number of alternatives. The actual payment of the interest could be delayed until the taxation return was received. Another alternative is that it could be paid when due, subject to the depositor declaring taxable income for the relevant year, even though a return may not have been actually submitted to the Taxation Office. In exactly the same way, of course, provisional taxpayers now may, if they choose, reassess their provisional tax liabilities at 31 March of any year for the income year ending the following June. Exactly the same thing could be done in this case. Of course, penalties would be provided for gross understatement of income, just as they are when people vary and grossly understate, provisional tax.

Senator Guilfoyle claimed that interest rates had increased quite significantly since the last amendment of this particular rate of interest occurred in August 1980. That is true. She said that market rates had increased, in one case, on Commonwealth bonds, by 3.15 per cent; and that therefore it would be less than reasonable if rates for income equalisation deposits were not increased by the nominal 2 1/2 per cent. What she is conveniently overlooking is that the effective rate of interest on the income equalisation deposits is not the nominal rate. She is attempting to defend this proposition by saying that because market rates for government bonds have gone up by 3 per cent that justifies an increase in the effective rate on income equalisation deposits, for people on the maximum marginal tax rate, of not 3 per cent but of 6 1/4 per cent. That is precisely what the increase in the effective rate is. The effective rate for maximum marginal taxpayers, which was 17 1/2 per cent before this statutory rule was introduced, has been increased not by 3 per cent but by 6 1/4 per cent, to 23.75 per cent.

Senator Guilfoyle said she had been advised that the interest was not paid in the way I am advocating-the way originally recommended by the Industries Assistance Commission. Senator Guilfoyle said last week: 'I am advised that it was not done in that way solely because of administrative impracticability'. I have just shown that it is not administratively impracticable to do it in that way. Indeed, for most deposits there would be no difficulty at all. For those in regard to which there would be some difficulties the adoption of similar arrangements to those which already apply to provisional taxpayers in reassessing their tax liability-it is called 'option to vary'-would overcome the problem. I do not believe that the Australian Taxation Office is so lacking in ingenuity that it could not work out a scheme at least as good as that. It took me about 20 minutes. I do not believe that the Australian Taxation Office, which has a number of extremely competent people, could not work out a scheme that would be at least as good as the one that I have worked out-if the Government were willing to allow it to do so, or willing to implement it. That is yet another spurious defence of this taxation rort.

In summary, I am more than a little disappointed with the Australian Democrats, not only because they are not supporting us but because they have again revealed an incapacity to see through a spurious argument of the type that has been put by the Government and by the National Farmers Federation. The small farmers, the welfare of whom the Governent purports to be concerned about, will not be helped by this statutory rule. Indeed, they will be harmed, firstly because it will attract outside capital into agriculture for the sole purpose of taking advantage of the taxation concession, as Mr Miller has outlined and, secondly, because in common with all taxation concessions where the benefits are disproportionately weighted in favour of farmers with high incomes, the position of the small, low income farmer vis-a-vis the higher income farmer will be weakened.

Of course, in respect of all the other reforms which ought to be made in this area, the Government having got away with this statutory rule, which has seriously exacerbated the effects of the tax haven which it previously engineered and constructed, the Senate has thrown away its only weapon to impose any discipline on the Government, to apply any effective pressure for reform. Had this decision not been taken we would have been in a strong bargaining position for the Government to reform these provisions, to make them operate in the way they were intended and ought to operate before they were sabotaged in 1976 and 1978 by decisions of this Government. That could have been a condition of supporting an increase in the interest rate in the way it ought to be applied, that is, on the net deposit of the tax deferred component.

As for Senator Guilfoyle, if that is the best defence the Government can offer no wonder the country is in a mess. The Minister for Finance does not understand that the way these IEDs now operate utterly contradicts the stated reason for their existence, that is, to enable farmers to avoid taxation penalties caused by varying taxable income, using IEDs to smooth out those variations in taxable income. According to Senator Guilfoyle only one week ago, that is what they do but in fact they do exactly the opposite. The way to minimise tax payable is to maximise the fluctuation in taxable income. Any farmer who uses income equalisation deposits in the way Senator Guilfoyle says they should be used will, in fact, incur a tax penalty and will pay more tax than would otherwise have been payable if no resort was had to income equalisation deposits. If she cannot understand it-and she obviously cannot-she might at least have looked at the table I made available to the Government last week, which gave the specifics of how this operated, or have got some decent advice, which she obviously has not.

I am very disappointed that this has happened. I thought that the Australian Democrats might have been serious about stopping tax avoidance and tax evasion. Obviously they are not. Senator Harradine has not declared himself. I hope that he will come into the vote that will be held on this matter and at least declare whether he is for or against protecting the tax havens which this Government has engineered and constructed.
