SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Health Amendment Bill 1981 is a short Bill and it has two unrelated functions, one of which is the result of the Government's administrative incompetence. The outcome of the Government's misguided and inequitable economic policy which seeks to heap on those who can least afford it more than their share of the economic burdens of this country makes up the second part of the legislation. The former corrects a mistake which is the result of the hasty and ill-conceived health charges which were introduced into this Parliament in May this year. The latter raises the cost of pharmaceuticals under the pharmaceutical benefits legislation from $2.75 to $3.20 per item, an increase of 45 cents.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the first part of the legislation. The mistake to be corrected results from the fact that in producing the legislation to deal with the new health arragements earlier this year the Government, amongst other things, abolished the hospital cost sharing agreements with all States with the exception of South Australia and Tasmania whose agreements had some years to run and whose governments-one Liberal and one Labor-recognised the inequities of the Government's proposals and would not have a bar of them. Not only were the proposals inequitable but also they were incompetent and not thought through. As a result the Government found itself in the position of paying the States a grant calculated to cover the costs of providing pharmaceuticals in public hospitals. In addition to this, because of the failure, as I said, to think things through, the Government found itself liable to reimburse the States for these pharmaceuticals under section 99 of the Health Insurance Act. This was potentially double dipping on a grand scale. We had the spectacle of Senator Peter Baume, then the Acting Minister for Health, coming into this chamber in September to say that the new health scheme was defective and that the Government intended to amend it when possible. Hence this Bill.

Since 1975 we have had six health schemes in this country. Each has had to be drastically changed after almost 12 months operation in each case. In this one the legislation was defective in conception and had to be adjusted only a couple of weeks after birth. We do not oppose the amendment. The whole scheme is inequitable and unfair but without this amendment it would be even more ludicrous. The States which oppose the new arrangements are amused and bemused by the incompetence of the Government. Those in the bureaucracy who have to attempt to translate the Government's hare-brained schemes into action are considering the agreements for similar mistakes and we will have to deal with those mistakes later.

This small amendment, like others, is a measure of the incompetence and lack of planning, and many such examples have littered and will litter the path of this benighted Government. The second section of the Bill intends to increase patient contributions to pharmaceutical benefits from $2.75 to $3.20 per item. It is in line with the Government's continued policy to introduce a user pays principle into our health scheme. The users in this case are the sick, particularly those with chronic illnesses and recurrent illnesses such as asthma, children with recurrent respiratory diseases, particularly those low income earners who qualify for assistance with health insurance but not pharmaceutical benefits and those who fall just outside the cut-off point for the disadvantage card. It is worth noting that large families with children in the years who suffer from childhood complaints such as recurrent upper respiratory tract infections are particularly heavy users of pharmaceutical benefits in the community. They are the families who will suffer the most from this proposal.

I believe it is worth thinking about another aspect of this problem. The usual justification for the introduction of a user pays principle is that in the market situation people have a choice of what goods and services they will buy and, therefore, they can regulate their expenditure according to their means and needs. The argument goes that they should therefore pay accordingly. This, as we have emphasised on numerous occasions in this place, does not apply to those who use and need pharmaceutical benefits, namely, the sick. Neither the nature of the purchase nor the time of purchase is the choice of the consumer. The time is dependent on illness and circumstances beyond the control of the patient and the choice of a pharmaceutical agent is almost entirely the choice of a third person, namely, the doctor. This is not a market situation in any normal sense; it never has been and it never will be. It is not appropriate that the user pays principle applies either in the pharmaceutical area or in the health area. It is the situation of an essential service needed by the patient and the provision of that service at a reasonable cost. The control of this is a legitimate function of government.

What is needed to be determined in the case of pharmaceuticals is, in fact, what is a reasonable cost. Any cost which places too large a financial burden on the patient or those in need, or limits access to health care by limiting access either to a doctor or to medicines, is too high. Both the present health system and the prescription charges which were introduced into this legislation will do this to a significant group of patients. It will make the cost too high. It is for this reason that we must look at this increase in pharmaceutical benefits in the context of the Government's new health insurance system.

Already there is a problem with prescription charges at $2.75. The Pharmacy Guild of Australia and individual pharmacists have produced plans which they believe will overcome the problems of low income and large families. They believe it will overcome the problems of those who need multiple items or repeat prescriptions but who they know, as practising pharmacists, cannot obtain the medicine they need or are limited in the number of medicines they can purchase through the pharmaceutical benefits system because of the cost. I think every member of this Senate has received either correspondence from or been approached by members of the Pharmacy Guild and individual pharmacists who are increasingly concerned with this problem which faces patients who have chronic and recurrent illnesses and who need continual medication. It is for this reason that these people, including Mr Hodges in another place, who is a pharmacist, continually talk about changing the scheme to bring the cost of pharmaceuticals to a reasonable level for this group of people.

It is not true, as Government spokesmen sometimes say, that the group which falls outside the disadvantage card group or those on benefits who cannot receive pharmaceutical benefits can go to public hospitals and public hospital pharmacies. There is not the distribution of public hospitals and such pharmacies throughout this country to enable them to do so. Since 1975 the increase in the cost of pharmaceutical items will have risen by 113 per cent, far in excess of the consumer price index over that time. If this increased cost is added to the increased costs involved under the new health insurance system we have a very real problem facing many low income earners and disadvantaged people in this community who need pharmaceuticals. It is for this reason that the Opposition will oppose these increases. This should hardly cause the Government much distress.

It is not easy to determine from an examination of the Budget Papers how much increased revenue to the Government will result from these increases. In the notes on Appropriation Bill (No. 1) the Government talks about $5.7m flowing from a number of factors including a variation in the mix of benefit items prescribed and a decline in the volume of prescriptions dispensed due to the removal of some items from the pharmaceutical benefits service list and, to a lesser degree, the increased patient contribution. This is a miniscule amount in the overall Budget. We believe that the combination of the new health insurance program and the increased pharmaceutical benefits represents an unsatisfactory system of health and access to health in this community. We believe that we should do everything we can to reduce the burden on people affected by the increased costs in this system. It is for this reason that in Committee we will oppose that part of the Bill which seeks to increase these charges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has already been pointed out tonight, there are two main purposes to the National Health Amendment Bill which is before us tonight. The first is to correct a Government oversight relating to the payment of funds to the States and the other is to increase the patient contribution for prescriptions under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, the first matter is a perfectly clear cut one. The Government made a mistake and is setting about correcting that mistake. It was a silly mistake but it could have been an expensive one. It is certainly not the first mistake that the Government has made this year and I doubt that it will be the last. We are certainly not going to put the Government in a position of not being able to correct the blunders that it makes. Of course, I think our attitude is particularly generous.

SPEECH.PARA: The second element of this Bill, however, relates to clause 3 which provides for an increase in the patient contribution for pharmaceuticals from $2.75 to $3.20-a 45c increase due to operate from 1 December and an increase which has been depicted by speakers from either side of the Senate as being something either akin to a Christmas present or a crime the magnitude of which is only slightly less than that of the great train robbery. It really is neither. In fact, the increase of 16 per cent since the last increase two years ago is considerably less than the increase of 50 per cent which the Labor Government introduced over the four year period to 1975. So even taken on an annual basis, this increase is by no means any worse than the increase in the pharmaceutical benefits rate that the Labor Government in 1975 was prepared to concede was necessary.

The major problem with the Bill is not what it says or what it does but what it does not say or does not do, and to a certain extent this has already been canvassed by Senator Grimes. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in his second reading speech said:

As in the past pensioners holding a pensioner health benefits card and their dependents will not be charged for pharmaceutical benefits. Similarly, no charge will be made for sickness beneficiaries holding a health benefits card and their dependants.

Unfortunately this benefit does not extend to some one million or so unemployed or otherwise disadvantaged people in the community unless they happen to have ready access to the outpatients department of a public hospital. This, of course, is not always possible, nor is it always desirable. I think most of us are aware of the fact that isolated patients do not have ready access to a public hospital. It is not even always easy for those living in cities where there are public hospitals with the appropriate out-patients departments. Some people have to catch several buses or make long trips across the city to get to those out-patients departments. This, of course, increases the cost to them. If the person concerned is a mother with, say, several small children the trip itself is a nightmare and the lengthy delay in the out-patients department of sometimes up to eight hours does not bear thinking about. I might add that this is not a criticism in any way at all of the staff of outpatient departments. They do the best they can under particularly trying circumstances.

It therefore seems rather ironic that, considering outpatient departments are almost by their very nature used to excess by the disadvantaged sections of the community, the situation has only worsened by the Government's allowing this anomaly to persist. Such a situation does not do anything to help anyone at all. It is in fact to prod the Government into ending this anomaly that the Democrats seek to move an amendment to the second reading of this Bill.
Accordingly, I move:
At end of motion, add:

', but the Senate is of the opinion that the Government should give urgent consideration to alleviating the burden on those unemployed and generally socially disadvantaged people who are not at present entitled to exemption or relief from the cost of pharmaceuticals'.

I refer honourable senators to the editorial in the October edition of The Australian Journal of Pharmacy. The editorial is headed 'Whose policy is this, Mr MacKellar?' The first sentence, the most pertinent one for my purposes tonight, states:
Australia, it can now be said, has achieved a bi-partisan policy in at least one area: that of payments under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme to drug manufacturers and pharmacists.

The rest of the article points out how similar the Government's attitudes are to those of the Labor Opposition in certain areas affecting health care and pharmaceutical benefits in particular. I can see no reason, therefore, why Australia cannot go one step further and adopt a bipartisan, or even a tripartisan, approach to the application of some sort of relief from the costs of pharmaceuticals for disadvantaged persons not at present eligible for assistance.

There is even more reason for my hopefulness on these grounds when we look at page 16 of the November edition of the AMA Gazette which discusses some of the Labor Party's attitudes to this suggestion. Certainly the Labor Party policy is not incompatible with it. The article states:
The Australian Labor Party is considering including pharmaceuticals in the new health insurance plan it is developing.

The party's Shadow Minister for Health, Dr Neal Blewett, told the annual meeting of the Australian Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association that such an approach might be the most effective to deal with a number of problems evident under present arrangements.

Of course, the problems that are evident under the present arrangements are apparent even to the mythical blind Freddy. They are concerned particularly with those who are chronically ill, those who have to look after the chronically ill and those who are in receipt of the disadvantaged persons card. They affect also, of course, those people who are just marginally over the income limit for access to a disadvantaged persons card. I was particularly pleased to hear Senator Grimes mention this problem since I hope that it indicates, if only tacitly, future Australian Labor Party support for the Australian Democrats' Health Act Amendment Bill (No. 2) which was introduced earlier this session and which seeks to overcome the anomaly which exists in the form of an absolute cut-off line for disadvantaged people by introducing a sliding scale system. That, however, is a debate which I dare say I will have out with Senator Grimes at some later stage.

I also believe or hope that all other parties in this Senate believe that those who can afford to pay should do so and that those who can afford to pay and do should subsidise those who cannot-a sort of income distribution scheme on a minor scale, if you like. That belief is certainly behind the Democrats' intention not to oppose outright clause 3 of the National Health Amendment Bill. We are not prepared to do that because, as our amendment to the second reading motion says, we believe that something must be done at present to end the anomaly whereby certain unemployed and socially disadvantaged people get no assistance from the Government for the cost of their pharmaceuticals. That is an anomaly which is clearly evident when one compares the benefits that are available to pensioners who have pensioner health benefit cards and whose incomes are highly unlikely to be any worse than the incomes of those on unemployment benefits or simply on low incomes.

So the Democrats are not prepared to oppose the minimal rise proposed by the Government in clause 3, in order-I stress that it is only in order-that the Government is given no excuse to duck its responsibility to the disadvantaged in the community by claiming that it has been denied funds, however minuscule Senator Grimes alleges they are, with which at least to begin to implement some sort of equalisation scheme. As I said earlier, figures are being flung around with gay abandon but apparently with very little regard either to actuality or to mathematic precision, and certainly not to the real issue at hand which is not how compatible the figures are-that is, the figures for cost of living increases vis-a-vis increases in pharmaceutical benefits-but whether the needy, the disadvantaged and the economically vulnerable can be protected from any cost, present or future, of medicines that they are likely to be forced to buy.

I had a phone call from Adelaide late this evening which alerted me to an article in today's News, the Adelaide afternoon newspaper. The article, on page 20 is headed: 'Cancer, poverty hit family'. It concerns a family named Woods which consists of a father who has cancer, a mother who has muscular dystrophy and five children who presumably are all healthy, since the article did not mention that there was anything other than normal childhood complaints wrong with them. Mr Woods has had a colostomy, because of which he needs on a regular basis suppositories which apparently, at least according to this article, are no longer on the free list. I am only going on the article and Senator Baume can correct me if that is not so. The point made is that he cannot afford the regular $14 that this medication costs. This is a fairly extreme case but when one takes into account the fact that they have to have a wheelchair for the wife, that she has a particularly disabling sickness and that they have five children who would not be normal if they did not come down with childhood complaints which require medication, one can see that the situation is indeed grim-extreme, but grim.

The general consensus within the industry is that the average person needs in the vicinity of five or six prescriptions a year; that is, an average, ordinary, relatively healthy person. The increase proposed by the Government of 45c in the contribution fee which these people will be expected to pay for those five or six prescriptions a year will amount to something like $2.70 per annum, an amount of money which is hardly likely to send the normal, working, average person to the wall. However, as I have said before and as Senator Grimes also pointed out, the problem lies not with those whose wage or income is the average weekly wage or better but with those whose wage or income is less than the average weekly wage, who are not pensioners entitled to the benefits of the pensioner health benefit card, who do not have ready access to out-patient departments of public hospitals and who are or who care for chronically ill people. I spent a considerable part of yesterday discussing not only my amendment but also clause 3 of the Bill with both the industry, represented by the Pharmacy Guild of Australia, and the Australian Council of Social Services, a group whose concern is predominantly with the have-nots in the community. I was pleased that both organisations not only shared my concern for those people in special need who are not at present being catered for but also agreed that the way around the situation is to allow clause 3 to pass and to induce the Government, by grovelling, pleading or something else, to use that money as a starting point for alleviating the financial hardship which is being forced--

TALK.START.PARA: —Any reasonable argument will do.

—I thank Senator Baume. I am being as reasonable and as reasoned as I possibly can, given the emotiveness of the topic. I am sure he appreciates that. Nevertheless, those organisations believe, as we believe, that that amount of money could be used a starting point for alleviating the financial burdens on those people in need who are not covered by some other means in the system that gives them exemption or relief from the cost of pharmaceuticals. It seems to me that if the Government is prepared to allow pensioners relief from the cost of pharmaceuticals purchased from a chemist and if it is prepared to repay the State governments, even if it does it only once and not twice, for their outlay on the provision of pharmaceuticals to the disadvantaged through out-patients departments, there is no reason why it cannot offer that same assistance to the disadvantaged by allowing them to get their scripts filled at a pharmacy by an ordinary chemist. It seems to me that there would be no greater cost to the Government and a lot less hardship and inconvenience, and extra cost, to the disadvantaged and the unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening at the moment-from memory I suspect that Senator Grimes touched upon this and certainly it is something about which the Pharmacy Guild is particularly concerned-is that chemists are being placed in an extremely invidious position. Customers are walking into their pharmacies with three or four or more scripts and saying 'We can only afford one. Please select the appropriate one, the best one for our needs'. That is asking a chemist not only to play God, which is bad enough, but also to do a job he is neither paid nor qualified to do. It is almost as bad as placing the mother of a child in the position of deciding herself, before she goes to the chemist, which of a series of prescriptions she will have filled for her child because she is unable to have the lot filled. The news release that the Pharmacy Guild of Australia put out yesterday sums up more than adequately the attitude of the Australian Democrats. As I said before, it is an attitude that ACOSS supports fully. Part of the Guild's position on the matter is as follows:

. . . 'While recognising the need for the Government to increase the patient contribution in line with inflation, provision needs to be made for those in special need. In the past our proposals have not been adopted on the grounds of difficulty in administration and cost of providing the concession.
The introduction of the health care card has provided a mechanism for identifying people to whom such concessions could be made available.'

The Guild claims that there is little point in providing those in special need with free medical attention, if they are unable to afford the patient contribution for medication prescribed by their medical practitioner.

'The Guild has again urged the Government to make a commitment to grant a significant concession on the patient contribution to health care card holders and to announce its intentions as a matter of urgency' . . .

There the news release ends. Tacitly implied in that is the point that it is not the 45c increase which is doing the damage; it is the original $2.75 cost which is becoming an intolerable burden for this relatively small group of people who are not able to take advantage of any other concession scheme. I put as strongly as I can to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) and to the Government that they seriously consider doing what the Democrats amendment requests; that is, to give urgent consideration to-indeed, to take urgent action-alleviating the burden on those unemployed and genuinely socially disadvantaged people who are not at present entitled to exemption or relief from the cost of pharmaceuticals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Laudable as the amendment moved by the Australian Democrats undoubtedly is, I have my reservations whether the Australian Labor Party would share the optimism of the Democrats that the Government will be persuaded to add another patch to, or to cobble or darn, the tattered garment which is all that remains of the National Health Scheme as we now see it. In the Australian Broadcasting Commission program Background Briefing of 23 August this year, Professor George Palmer of the Department of Health Administration, University of New South Wales, spoke of the increasing privatisation of health services. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . The total amount of private medicine being practised, and I mean private fee for service medicine, both within private and public hospitals, is likely to be increased, or at least there are going to be pressures to increase. So there's no question that the big winners, the people who are most likely to benefit most, are those who one can broadly describe as being the private sector.

Of course that is what we are seeing. Every successive change in health services is inexorably adding to the advantage of the private sector and subtracting from public access to quality health care. Increasing the patient contribution by about 15 per cent, which is what this 45c increase will do, and despite the Government's own calculation of a 10 per cent or an 11 per cent increase in wages over the next 12 months, may not at first glance appear to be particularly significant. Many people, however, especially families on low household incomes, those who are chronically ill and those with children, have over the past six or eight years come to rely on government hospitals for their out-patient treatment because for one reason or another they have been unable to receive the advantage of bulk billing from a private practitioner. Now, unless they are very poor and entitled to a health card or are comfortably situated and privately insured, they may be without any assistance at all. Previously they could use out-patient consulting facilities and be supplied with drugs from the hospital pharmacy free of charge. Nasty shocks are in store for many such low income earners because now in most cases they will be required to pay $15 for each out-patient visit plus the $3.20 which will now be the cost of each prescription.

Community health services are also being forced to charge all but pensioners and card holders. Certainly this is the case in all Western Australian government hospitals. Late last year when changes to hospital funding were being anticipated the Western Australian Government issued instructions to all the hospital pharmacists restricting the maximum allowable on each prescription to seven days supply for emergency outpatients, 14 days supply for out-patients under specialist treatment and 14 days supply for in-patients under specialist treatment. No larger quantity was to be dispensed except with the express permission of the hospital administrator. This directive meant that those who depended on the local hospital for their contraceptives, for example, could no longer be prescribed oral contraceptives, for which of course monthly or two-monthly packs are the only rational method of dispensing.

At the same time many people, some young, some not so young, are without the only low cost source of family planning advice that had previously been available to them. Family planning clinics, where they exist, are battling to maintain adequate services with diminishing funds. Oral contraceptives can still be provided at a slighly discounted rate through the family planning services but for a growing proportion of women-up to 50 per cent-who choose another method of contraception there is nowhere they can go to obtain devices or advice free of charge. In Western Australia a diaphragm costs from $10 to $15 an intra-uterine device costs from $15 to $20, and family planning clinics have no choice but to pass the cost on to the woman concerned. The Family Planning Association says that since 1 September about 20 per cent of those previously eligible for bulk billing must now pay as they fall outside the income test.

The King Edward Memorial Hospital for Women is now forced to charge all out-patients $15 for each consultation plus $3 for each prescription. Community health care workers confirm that where the family is poor money is found for the children's health care but women's health tends to be neglected. Obviously the intention of this Government and of the State Government of Western Australia is to force people to attend private practitioners, regardless of their circumstances or of their personal preference. It has been suggested to me that sensitive, reliable, skilled general practitioners are so busy that one waits weeks for an appointment even where the choice is financially viable.

Public hospital treatment, after all, is what our taxes provide. It is surely a sign of an abysmally inept and callous government if any individual is deprived of medical care or essential medication because of inability to afford it, and this is where the policies of this Government are leading. Hospital treatment is becoming more expensive and therefore less accessible. The theory is, of course, that most people can afford private advice. But we know that the burden of medical insurance is only one of the many recent financial punishments meted out to Australian workers and their families. Doctors and chemists bills may well be the last straw for families already struggling to make ends meet after coping as best they can with rising housing loan repayments, high income tax, heavy transport costs and vicious State charges.
Professor Opit of the School of Social and Preventive Medicine at Monash University, during the Background Briefing program to which I previously referred, made the following comment:

What the Government has done, it seems, is not to have understood history . . . Neither the very rich nor the very poor who tend to be polarised in their voting patterns are going to be greatly affected.

Clearly those who will be affected are low income earners eligible for health cards but not for pharmaceutical benefits; those who are marginally better off but who are ineligible for a health card and not able to afford health insurance but faced with heavy hospital costs if they do not insure; and the chronically ill. There are also significant numbers who have returned to the work force after extensive surgery or after very serious illness but who will need medication, often in large quantities and of a number of different kinds, for the rest of their lives. An extra 45c on each repeat of each prescription is an impost that these people could do without, especially those in the same position as the Western Australians who had expected that life supporting drugs would continue to be available free of charge and in appropriate quantities through the government hospitals. Such people are often the owners of prescription books, similar to the one that I have in my hand, which tend to become volumes over a few years. This one has been current for five years. It has just become useless. This book belongs to a Western Australian who developed an extremely severe liver disease from which he was fortunate to recover. For the last five years and until very recently he had been able to receive from the government hospital reasonable quantities of the drugs that he required-up to three months supply of anything up to a range of seven medications which he must have if he is to remain in the work force, continuing to pay taxes--

TALK.START.PARA: —Seven medications?
—Six and a lotion; I beg your pardon.
—As a specialist in liver disease I cannot imagine any illness for which anyone would need seven medications.

—Senator Baume, you are welcome to examine this. This man is now forced to attend his general practitioner and to come away with a sheaf of prescriptions, and very soon he will have to pay $3.20 for each repeat of each drug.

SPEECH.PARA: Professor Opit clearly states his position, and it makes eminent sense. He says:

We need to have a public utility system that is the responsibility of the government. It should not be means tested: If you pay income tax you are financing the system. And then outside that I want to see if people and doctors want to provide a private consumption system which can do anything it likes and if people want to pay for that by agreement then that's their right. But I want the two systems disentangled and at present they are hopelessly entangled.

I add that this is to the disadvantage of such people as we have been discussing tonight. Over the years there have been calls for the cessation of hospital outpatient dispensing. What is happening now is a blatant attempt to price all outpatient care out of reach, which indirectly has the same effect. The result can only be deterioration in the health of the nation, further stress for families already under severe financial pressure and more unplanned pregnancies. Is this what the Government sets out to achieve?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to Senator Haines's amendment which, in fact, seeks to add to the motion this expression of opinion-'that the Government should give urgent consideration to alleviating the burden on those unemployed and generally socially disadvantaged people who are not at present entitled to exemption or relief from the cost of pharmaceuticals.' Of course, the Opposition has no objection to this amendment; we will support it. We will support it in the knowledge that in fact it does very little but perform the useful function of expressing a view and highlighting a group of people in the community who are obviously disadvantaged. The Government, in its new health scheme, has chosen the group to be disadvantaged. It has chosen to give most of them access to health insurance and health care without access to pharmaceutical benefits. I do not share Senator Haines's hopes that the Government will take notice of that amendment.
—We must keep trying.

—We must keep trying and we must live in hope. I suppose that is all that keeps some people in this place-even some people in this country-going. In fact, the first legislative act of this Government after achieving power in 1975 was to abolish the subsidised health and pharmaceutical benefit scheme of the time. Although I share the honourable senator's hopes, perhaps I do not have the confidence that she has that the Government will in fact take notice of the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another point I would like to make about the matter. Even if the Government does take up Senator Haines's proposal it will still leave out a large group of people in the community who are disadvantaged, particularly that group of people of whom Senator Haines has spoken in the past and about whom I have spoken. I refer to people who fall just outside the cut off point for the new disadvantaged cards. In fact the Government's scheme for disadvantaged cards bears little relationship to need. It is a crude measurement. For example, consider the situation of a family of a husband, wife and two children just below the cut off point who will receive access to health care and who, under Senator Haines's proposal, will receive free pharmaceutical benefits; as indeed they should. The problem is that families $1 or $2 above the level with the same number of children will get nothing. They will have to pay health insurance and the increased pharmaceutical benefit costs. The family just under the level may have healthy children, and the adults may be healthy, but the family just over the level may have asthma, epilepsy or other chronic and/or recurrent illness. Therefore, under this scheme there is no relationship to need at all.

Of course, we also have situations like this: A 16-year-old or 17-year-old living at home and earning $95 a week will get a disadvantaged card but an adult with a chronic illness, earning slightly more money, will not get a disadvantaged card and, under Senator Haines's proposal, will get no free pharmaceuticals. Although we agree that this group should get free or reduced pharmaceutical benefits we would not like to give the impression, in our support of the amendment, that in fact we think this is an answer to the inequities of our present health insurance and health scheme generally. As Senator Giles pointed out, and as I believe I pointed out, in a health system, in both the provision of health services and pharmaceuticals, it is quite inappropriate to apply the sort of market mechanisms which exist in the provision of other goods and services in the community.

I repeat what I said before: The patient can choose neither the time that he needs the services nor the time that he needs the pharmaceuticals. In fact, the patient does not choose what services he will receive or what pharmaceuticals he will receive. That choice is made by another person-the doctor. Therefore, patients cannot adjust their expenditure to suit their needs or their means. Until we recognise this, until we provide a health system such as is provided in most European countries, Canada and other places, one that is public whereby this burden is not placed on people who cannot afford it at that time, or who cannot afford it at any time because of their low incomes, we will not have a fair and equitable health system. If people want to go outside that system, if people want to opt out of the public scheme and enter into a private health insurance system, so be it; but the provision should be available under a universal health scheme for all citizens in the community. That scheme should include the provision of pharmaceuticals. Therefore, we support the Australian Democrats' amendment more in hope than faith that anything will come of it. We will persist with our opposition to clause 3 when the Committee stage is reached.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is considering a National Health Amendment Bill with two legs to it. Honourable senators who have spoken already have indicated that there is support for the first part of the Bill which seeks to correct an anomaly which has arisen following the amendments introduced earlier this year. I thank honourable senators for that support. I understand that the Australian Democrats will be supporting the second part of the Bill which seeks to increase the patient contribution for pharmaceutical products obtained under this scheme. The debate really has not concerned itself so much with those two matters. It has concerned itself with a number of problems at the margin; a number of problems of people who may not be covered by the scheme and for whom there is some concern that in fact they could be better catered for under the arrangements that we have in this country. The Government is aware of this problem. It is keen to see debates such as this occur.

SPEECH.PARA: If we look at the new arrangements we will find that health insurance for three out of every four Australians-when we take account of all the measures involved in the new health insurance scheme-is cheaper than it was previously. That is so when we take into account the very considerable contributions the Government has made, for example by way of $200m to the reinsurance trust funds, the fact that there is now a flat rate reimbursement of 30 per cent for all medical benefit items as a Commonwealth benefit, the fact that it has relieved the health insurance funds of the burden of paying nursing home benefits for insured persons-that is a further Commonwealth Government subvention of $120m a year-and, of course, by providing a tax rebate of 32c in the dollar for those who take out health insurance. The package adds up to one which has very real costs by way of subvention.

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not help the people who are above the tax threshold who are not paying tax.

—I have not yet tried in any way to make fun of or not take seriously the very fair contribution that the honourable senator has made. The point I make is that, whatever action we take, it will be necessary to match our revenue capacity against what we want to do by way of subvention. For better or for worse, we chose a series of options for the subventions we could make this year. The amount that went into the reinsurance fund was a decision, a choice between priorities. The $120m for nursing homes was a choice. The tax rebate was a choice. That does not mean that the Government cannot consider further choices or further options.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say as a doctor, and as a doctor who is a specialist physician, that one of the great banes of my life was the problem of overmedication, unnecessary medication and inappropriate medication. I might say to honourable senators that, as a matter of fact, a large amount of the medication used in this country is ineffective, inappropriate or unnecessary. That does not alter the fact-I do not move away from the argument Senator Haines and others have put-that there is a part of medication which is both necessary and appropriate. However, I make the point that polypharmacy generally-not always but generally-indicates sloppy medicine. That is why I was concerned at the example Senator Giles gave.

TALK.START.PARA: —But the patient is still paying for it.
—I am not blaming anyone.
—They are still paying.

—I am just saying that that is one other part of the problem. Of course, in relation to the proposed increase in the patient contribution, we are following a well trodden path. The Australian Labor Party when in government, Senator Grimes when in government, supported an increase of 50 per cent in the patient contribution on one occasion. In 1975 the Australian Labor Party supported an increase from $1 to $1.50 in the patient contribution. What does that prove? It proves nothing more than that the principle has been well established: That the patient contribution is there, can be increased and can be increased by socialist as well as non-socialist governments. If it was proper for it to be increased by the Labor Party in 1975, it is equally proper for it to be increased now. Senator Grimes is laughing. If he wants to argue the point later I will produce a whole series of indices.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to devote my remarks to the amendment moved by Senator Haines and to the propositions she advanced. I say to her that it probably is not appropriate for the Government to support her amendment to the motion that this Bill be read a second time. Having said that, I say to her that the sentiment expressed in her amendment-namely, that consideration should be given to a particular aspect-is one which will be brought straight away to the attention of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar). If there are at the margin problems which require a further subvention, further effort or initiatives by government, that is something which we will make sure that we take on board and examine. Yes, at the present time patients who have health care cards can get relief through public hospitals. Yes, there may be some disadvantages in their doing that, but some exemption and relief is possible.

The honourable senator said that she wanted a different model. She named a particular model which she thought might be appropriate. I am perfectly happy to look at that model, but whether the extension of the pensioner medical scheme for pharmaceuticals is an appropriate way of achieving what she wants to achieve I do not know. One of the problems we face is that, with the best will in the world, it is very difficult to know with any certainty exactly what the size of the problem is. If honourable senators were to think about it they would realise that most of the comments we have heard have been anecdotal comments-they have been the impressions of people in either pharmacy practice or medical practice-on the extent of the problem. We can identify-Senator Grimes has done so-where some of the problems might lie. I hope that we can look at whether it is possible to get an idea of the dimensions of the problem and of what might be the size of the subvention needed. We take on board the problem raised by the Australian Democrats. The Minister for Health has indicated that he certainly will look at it. Whilst we do not support the proposed amendment, we adopt that approach on that basis, with a great degree of goodwill and with a considerable degree of agreement on the concern expressed by Senator Haines in moving her amendment. I commend the Bill.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 3 of the National Health Amendment Bill has the effect of increasing to $3.20 the patient contribution for pharmaceutical benefits and, of course, excludes people who hold pensioner medical cards and others. The Opposition opposes this clause. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Senator Baume, in summing up for the Government at the second reading stage of the Bill, suggested that what we were in fact dealing with was a problem around the margins. The problem with those margins is that within them are people who are ill, people who frequently have recurrent illnesses, and people who can ill afford not only the pharmaceuticals which they require-many of them have no access to the pharmacies of public hospitals-but also the increased health insurance costs or, alternatively, the very high health costs they would have to pay if they did not take out health insurance. These people may be considered by the Government to be on the margins, but they are real, live people who deserve the concern of this community and whose problems would be assisted, initially, by a universal health insurance scheme and, secondly, by a scheme which included pharmaceuticals.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Baume introduced an argument which we hear often from the other side of the chamber. He, as a doctor, pointed out that there was considerable overmedication, inappropriate medication and unnecessary medication in the community and that the practice of polypharmacy often represented this. I, as a doctor, could not agree with him more. I assume that the only reason he introduced this argument was to take up the point which, as I said, is so often taken up on that side of the chamber; namely, that something can be done about this, that indeed it is appropriate for something to be done about this, by imposing a penalty by increasing the cost of pharmaceuticals. I repeat, as I have many times in this place: If there is overmedication, and there is, if there is inappropriate medication, and there is, if there is unnecessary medication, and there is, it is not the fault of the patient in this country.

The problem is not solved by increasing the cost of pharmaceuticals or by imposing a penalty on people requiring access to health care in this community. It must be solved at the level of the doctor. We must, if necessary, reduce the expectations of people in this community for various forms of treatment, including pharmaceutical treatment. If Senator Baume did not bring that matter in as an argument, I do not know why he brought it up at all. But we have heard it so often from him and other honourable senators on that side of the chamber that one can assume that he is bringing up that old furphy again. He mentioned that so much of the evidence of the difficulties faced by people in the community in relation to this matter was, in fact, anecdotal. I assume that he was partly referring to the anecdotal but true story--

TALK.START.PARA: —It does not invalidate it.
—It does not invalidate it at all. I refer to the true story which was produced by Senator Haines and Senator Giles.
—I am making the point that it is not quantitative.

—It is not quantitative. The honourable senator also mentioned the pharmacists and the Pharmacy Guild of Australia. The Pharmacy Guild, which represents almost every pharmacist in this country, has said that there is a problem of people who cannot afford to pay the present $2.75 per item; and how much greater will the problem be when the cost is increased to $3.20. The Government may solve some of its problems of overmedication by people not being able to afford it but unfortunately people who need the medication will not be able to afford it or will avoid paying for it altogether. I thought that Senator Baume's best and most extraordinary argument was that it was appropriate for the Government to increase the cost of pharmaceutical benefits prescriptions because the Labor Government did so in 1975. I suggest that it is appropriate for the Government to introduce a universal health insurance scheme, which the Labor Government did. Many other matters are appropriate, but surely it is phoney for Senator Baume to introduce such an argument, particularly as his government has increased the cost of pharmaceuticals by 113 per cent since it came into power. I point out that that is far in excess of the consumer price index increase.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe this legislation cannot be taken in isolation and that one cannot consider in isolation the cost of pharmaceuticals to the patients of this country. One has to consider it in the light of the inequitable health insurance scheme that has been introduced. One has to consider it in the light of the increased costs of health insurance and health care which will be imposed on many people in this community who cannot afford them. One has to consider the legislation in light of the fact that it involves a flat rate payment which bears no relation to what people can afford to pay. In the light of all those facts we believe that the least we can do as a party is to say to the Government that it should stop making these changes. The Government should take out the tiny cost to the revenue which is involved in this increase from $2.75 to $3.20, go away to consider not only the proposals contained in Senator Haines's amendment-to bring in that limited group of disadvantaged people-but also, over the next three months, the very real difficulties which many people in the community will face because of these increased costs. If the Government does this and looks at it fairly I believe it will come up with a proper health insurance scheme. It is for this reason that as well as supporting, as we did, the amendment moved by Senator Haines, we persist in our opposition to clause 3 of the Bill. This clause seeks to impose an added injustice in the health system of this community. We will persist with our opposition. Whether anyone else goes along with us is immaterial. We are concerned about the costs in general of health care, including pharmaceuticals, to the ordinary men and women of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make one or two comments in relation to clause 3 of the National Health Amendment Bill 1981. I covered the matter, I think, fairly adequately in my speech at the second reading stage. For the record I wish to itemise again the reasons the Australian Democrats will not oppose this increase. The first is that in the last two years there has been an increase of something like 16.4 per cent compared with-if one must make comparisons-the 25 per cent a year increase that took place between 1971 and 1975 when the Labor Government introduced its increases. As I was a mathematician before I became a member of the Senate, I know what can be done with figures; one can do practically anything.
—You are doing it.

—Indeed, I am doing it because it seems to be the going game. I agree with Senator Grimes that it is pointless to say that the Liberal Government is increasing the patient contribution by 16.4 per cent when Labor did it by a much more substantial amount. That is pointless. As I said earlier, the increase of 45c is nothing to people who are disadvantaged in comparison with the $2.75 which is already there. It is the $2.75 which is the stumbling block, not the 45c increase. I believe, however naive that belief may be, that it is better to give the Government an opportunity to use the $5.7m-or whatever amount Senator Grimes said would be raised from this increase-for the benefit of those disadvantaged people. I do not agree with Senator Grimes that they are a small group of people. In a country which has a population of slightly in excess of 15 million, I can not see how he can define a group of one million or close to it as being small.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendment that the Australian Democrats moved and had passed to the second reading motion is one which does ask that the economic burden on one million people be alleviated by giving them some exemption or relief from the cost of pharmaceuticals. It is for that reason I cannot fathom the incongruity or illogicality of agreeing with the hopes expressed-however pious and however unlikely to come to fruition Senator Grimes seems to think they are-in that second reading amendment and then cutting off the Government's access to that, I agree, relatively small amount of money which may induce the Government to take action. It seems to me to be cutting off the nose of the disadvantaged to spite the political face of the Australian Labor Party. The Democrats believe the Government has the right to be given the opportunity to show whether it has any scruples. In doing so, I am prepared to sacrifice that $5.7m to the potential greater good of one million disadvantaged people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been provoked by Senator Haines. Senator Haines seems to believe that by my remarks-I hope that when I read Hansard I will see there is no justification for what she seems to believe-I was inferring that the problem of the unemployed and the generally socially disadvantaged people, who as she said, comprise of about one million people in this community, was a small problem involving a small group. I used the expression 'small' in referring to the suggestion of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) that what we are talking about was this group of people around the margins. The Opposition and I supported Senator Haines's amendment because obviously there is a case for providing pharmaceutical benefits to that group of unemployed and generally disadvantaged people. My qualifications on that support were that I did not share her hope that the Government would do much.

SPEECH.PARA: The second qualification I had was that large numbers of people are outside the scope of that amendment. Perhaps that group will come into the scope of Senator Haines's private member's Bill which she intends to introduce at a later time and will, in fact, not be affected by her amendment and by any Government action, however unlikely that may be. It is because we are concerned about all people inside and outside that group that we persist with our opposition to clause 3. We do not think that the number of people involved is small, nor do we think that their problems are small. We believe that their problems can be solved only by a comprehensive and universal health scheme. If I suggested to Senator Haines in anything that I said that either I or the Opposition think that this is only a small group and that their problems are small, I apologise. I will be more careful with my words in future. I am just disappointed that Senator Haines thinks that we or any party in this Parliament should be in the game of bartering off one group against another. We cannot understand why Senator Haines and her colleagues will not persist in opposing clause 3 as well as with the amendment that they have moved, but that is their choice; they must make their own decision. They chose to oppose tertiary education fees, using logic which I suggest is hardly consistent with their failure to oppose clause 3; but logic does not always apply in political arguments in this place. I reiterate that we persist in our opposition to clause 3.
Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last evening the Committee was discussing points which had been raised by Senator Grimes about the dispute which for a considerable period has plagued the Department of Social Security. It must be said that, despite the contribution made by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), the Opposition is not satisfied that everything that should be done is being done to resolve this vexed question of stand-downs and industrial disputation which is disrupting social security payments in New South Wales and Victoria and may become more extensive. I think the Senate was entitled to expect that the Government would have handled this dispute in a much better way with a view to resolving the differences that clearly exist.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not believe that public servants as a whole are responsible. We do not believe that the Administrative and Clerical Officers Association, which covers the public servants, is also irresponsible. In fact, the evidence shows that this dispute is the first industrial experience a great majority of the members of the Department of Social Security who have been stood down have had. Surely it has to be recognised by the Minister and the Government that the members concerned have a genuine grievance. They believe that the policies being pursued by the Government, which can generally be related to the area of cutbacks in the work force, are not commensurate with the extra responsibilities that the members of that Department have been called upon to carry out. The members believe that despite some improvement by the Government in the numbers employed in the work force there is still a need for considerably more staff to be employed.

Of course, this situation flows from decisions made by this Government over the last several years which were designed to affect the number of persons employed in all of the government departments. When the situation reaches the point where staff ceilings have the effect of creating disaffection and inefficiencies and where the industrial relations in the Department have deteriorated to the degree that they have, I think the Senate is entitled to expect of the Government a much more co-operative attitude and a better determination to resolve the differences that clearly exist.

The Government should not just see the acts done at the head of the Department level. They can only be described as provocative and needling. Over the years the members of the staff have given yeoman service to the public while working in a very difficult area. These officers have to deal people in our society who are disadvantaged and who, in many cases, feel that they need compassion and understanding of the sorts of problems they face when they go to discuss these problems at the counter and seek interviews, whether they be about unemployment benefits or other social security payments. We find that the Department and the Government are adopting what can only be described as a dog in the manger attitude, an attitude of obstinancy. They are saying that they are not prepared to resolve the dispute until the work bans have been lifted. The fact is that the dispute has been simmering for more than two years.

It must surely be of concern to the Senate that nobody is winning this issue. The Government is standing pat and the staff is standing pat. The social security beneficiaries are the people who are affected by this obstinate attitude. I do not think it is proper that the Government should take the view that it will tough out this dispute on the basis that the ACOA, which is the appropriate Association covering the employees, is somehow or other involved in some sort of ideological struggle with the Government. Enough evidence is available to show that close to 400 officers have been stood down. They were not just officers at the lower end of the scale; some senior people were involved. These officers responded because of the extra tasks they have been given as part of their normal daily duties. It just stands to reason that they would object. The very strong criticism that has been made of the Public Service Board in recent days by appropriate authorities in the industrial field indicates that one does not need to have the wisdom of Solomon to appreciate that if workers are given tasks over and above their normal tasks one can expect a reaction. That happens to be part of human nature. If management persists in that process, inevitably it leads to industrial conflict and dispute of this nature.

The Association has been suggesting that, because of the razor gang cuts, extra tasks have been allocated to the staff of the Department of Social Security, tasks which were previously carried out by the Commonwealth Employment Service, and that there are established forms and processes by which these matters are normally resolved. Of course, this has led to a breakdown in relations with the Government. The Minister says that it is a matter for his departmental head and that he is not prepared to become involved until the work bans have been lifted. I think it was Senator Chaney who said on 2 July that the staff ceilings for the Department would be increased by 152 and that additional steps would be taken to increase that number. But the following day the Federal Secretary of the ACOA, Mr Paul Munro, said that that number was not sufficient and that this statement contradicted negotiations and an understanding the union had with the Department. It contradicted a June 1980 joint departmental-ACOA working party report stating that the Department needed at least 500 extra staff for relief purposes. That undertaking was given, of course, prior to the additional tasks being allocated to the Department of Social Security arising out of changes in areas of responsibility.

There has clearly been a breakdown in relations at the departmental level and that is causing us a great deal of concern. Certainly, in adequate steps are being taken to resolve this dispute. Internal departmental reviews have been carried out by senior departmental officers. One of those reports showed that in New South Wales alone there was an immediate need for more relief staff to be employed. The other report, dealing with Victoria, showed that in regional areas there was an immediate need for a considerable amount of relief and additional staff to be allocated. But that has not happened. The situation is that the Minister is relying upon the niceties of the relationship between himself and the departmental head. The Director-General has refused to negotiate with the ACOA and the Minister has indicated both in the discussion on this matter in this chamber as well as in reply to questions asked by honourable senators, particularly by Senator Grimes, that he is not prepared to take any steps to resolve the matter. How much longer will this go on? It seems when we have a stand-off position-one can only describe it as such-somebody must break the impasse and take the initiative. Surely it is a matter of concern to the Senate to know that as a result of staff ceilings-we raised this matter in an Estimates committee-the Government is losing money in the collection of tax. Tax evasion is proceeding because of cutbacks in staff in the Taxation Office.

Let us look at what is happening as a result of the low staffing levels and at what that means in terms of government revenue, particularly in the area where there are outstanding overpayments. In 1977-78, for example, outstanding payments were $21.3m and 51 per cent of that money was collected as a result of departmental activities. The following year the figure increased and 58 per cent of the money that had been overpaid was collected. But as a result of staff ceilings in the current year-1980-81-when overpayments are $45m the collection rate is down to 35 per cent. So if honourable senators apply some mathematics to that they will see that the Government is losing revenue as a result of its philosophical position of not putting on sufficient staff to collect the money. By having a stagnant staff position and by refusing to negotiate, the Government is failing to collect money that is due to it.

Consequently of course the Department of Social Security is conscientious enough to believe that the state of affairs is unsatisfactory and that the actions which it has taken to protect the public interest are also affecting the beneficiaries of social security payments. We expect the Government to take such steps as will resolve this current difficulty. It is pretty clear that whilst the Government has been pressed to increase staff levels there is not sufficient staff in the Department to overcome the problems that obviously exist. The staff is not sufficient to cover the new tasks that the Department of Social Security has to provide. The Department has not been given sufficient permanent staff and it still has some difficulties about retraining programs which it believes are essential in the Department. SPEECH.PARA: I return relatively briefly to the industrial matter. I would like the chamber to be quite clear on my view as to where responsibilities lie with respect to Ministers and departments. I refer briefly to the Constitution. It is certainly my view that Chapter II of the Constitution makes it clear that Ministers are responsible for the administration of departments of state. Section 64 of the Constitution refers to that, and states:

The Governor-General may appoint officers to administer such Departments of State of the Commonwealth as the Governor-General in Council may establish. Such officers shall be the Queen's Ministers of State for the Commonwealth.

I accept the responsibility that that section of the Constitution imposes. I think honourable senators would also be familiar with the provisions of the Social Services Act and the Public Service Act which further define the position. The Social Services Act provides:
There shall be a Director-General of Social Services, who shall, subject to any direction of the Minister, have the general administration of this Act.

He also has powers of appointment, delegation and so on. The point I made in Question Time the other day which has given rise to a series of statements by Senator Grimes as to my seeking to place responsibility on officers was that the general administration is, of course, in the hands of public servants but in whosever hands it is, I am responsible for what they do. That is quite clear. I do not seek to escape that and I do not think I have ever said anything which would suggest that I do. I regard this as a somewhat important matter and for that reason I would like to put the record straight. I refer also to the Public Service Act which makes quite clear what the duties of permanent heads are. I refer to sub-section 25 (2), which states:
The permanent head of a Department shall be responsible for its general working, and for all the business thereof, and shall advise the Minister in all matters relating to the Department.
Once again, I do not believe that that statutory duty which is placed on the permanent head by the Public Service Act in any way affects the responsibility of the Minister.

The last time we were dealing with these appropriations Senator Grimes raised a series of specific concerns about the treatment of individual officers. I made it clear, I think, at that time that certainly I would not and did not direct that there should be any selective application of stand-downs, that the no work as directed situation should be applied generally. That was the position as I understood it. In light of the specific matters raised by Senator Grimes I sought from my Department specific advice with respect to the matters that he raised. I will now read from that advice which has been provided for me and which I think indicates that the concerns which he expressed are misplaced. I quote firstly from the document signed by the Director of the Department of Social Security in New South Wales. It reads:

The next reference is to the Camperdown office. The name Steve Bolt was mentioned. The report to me reads as follows:
The Manager who took the standdown action is on recreation leave and cannot be contacted. However, the witness to the second standdown instruction issued at--

I simply say that I think the Estimates Committee procedure-as honourable senators observed when we were dealing with earlier Estimates Committee reports-ought to lead to debates in this chamber on issues raised in those Committees rather than a repetition of the same sort of exercise.

SPEECH.PARA: However, I will address myself to the matters raised by Senator Giles. Of course, she is entitled to raise those matters here. That is any honourable senator's right. The question she first raised concerned how I can square my concern for taxpayers with the consideration of a pilot project to assist lower income people to attend commercial child care centres. I have expressed concern over a series of matters that I have discovered in this program which indicate to me that some people on modest or low incomes have difficulty in getting benefit from those parts of the program which are subsidised by my Department. If Senator Giles casts her mind back to the Estimates Committee, I gave an example of a centre in Victoria which had had capital subsidy in excess of $300,000, was getting recurrent subsidy of approximately $86,000, was catering for no more than 60 children and yet was charging fees which the operators of the service said put it beyond the means of many of the people that they wished to serve. That is one of the areas about which I am concerned. I think we have to look at the funding mechanism to make sure that those centres are available to people who need them most.

As far as the commercial centres are concerned, when one looks at the statistics and sees that there are a very large number of non-subsidised centres which operate in the child care field and which, because they are unsubsidised, have to charge a full cost, in seems to me that it may well be we can open up the opportunities for people on lower incomes to get access to something more than casual child minding arrangements if they can be assisted to attend commercial centres where they are the centres which are available to them in a geographic sense. As I said in the Estimates Committee, that matter is not very far advanced. The pilot project has not been designed. It aims at examining whether greater access could be provided by the use of that sort of mechanism. As for the question of how people can be expected to pay $80 a week, I make it quite clear that my concern is that there are low income families who cannot afford the present subsidised rates. I would wish to see something done about that. But in a situation described by Senator Grimes in the Estimates Committee as one where there are almost limitless demands-I think I quote him accurately-I cannot see an end to some rationing of government money going into child care. I believe that that rationing ought to be in favour of those who are less well off and those who have a greater social need. In light of the hour I will seek leave to continue my remarks later.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 18 August 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has a precedent been set by the granting of compensation to a victim of radiation poisoning at the Maralinga nuclear test facility.
(2) Are payments pending to other radiation victims from Maralinga.

(3) Is compensation available to dependents of victims who did not survive radiation poisoning; if so, what are the details of compensation paid and the medical criteria under which compensation was assessed.
(4) What are the criteria for persons who seek to apply to the Government for similar compensation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Commissioner for Employees' Compensation deals with each case on its individual merits, and as has been done in cases dealt with to date, he will rely on specialist medical opinion to determine future cases as they arise.

Recently the Commonwealth was found to be liable to pay compensation in the case of a Royal Australian Air Force Squadron Leader who had been exposed to radiation while performing duty as a member of aircrew at Emu Claypan in South Australia. This case attracted considerable publicity in the media. However, there had been one earlier case in which liability was found in respect of the effects of exposure to radiation. The case arose from a claim by the widow of an Army Warrant Officer who was a member of a detachment which recovered a centurion tank from a fall-out area of atomic tests conducted at Emu Claypan. The Commonwealth was found to be liable to pay compensation in this case in the light of specialist medical opinion from an expert in cancer cases. From the available evidence, the delegate was satisfied that on the balance of probability there was a connection between the Warrant Officer's death and his exposure to radioactive dust.
On the other hand, 14 claims have been disallowed since March 1980; one of these is the subject of an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.
If the case of the Royal Australian Air Force Squadron Leader is the one that the honourable senator had in mind in asking his question, in view of the foregoing it cannot be regarded as a precedent.
(2) No payments of compensation are pending in any other cases, but 46 claims are currently under investigation in relation to alleged exposure arising from United Kingdom atomic tests in Australia.

(3) Yes. In the case of the Army Warrant Officer referred to at (1) above, compensation of $8,600 was awarded under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act in accordance with the level of benefit prescribed at the date of death. Weekly payments of compensation at the prescribed rates were also made to the widow initially in respect of four dependent children. At present payment is continuing at the rate of $14.20 per week in respect of one student child.

(4) For liability to be found under the Compensation (Commonwealth Government Employees) Act the Commissioner for Employees' Compensation or his delegate must be satisfied that the employee sustained personal injury arising out of or in the course of the employment, or suffered from a disease, the contraction, aggravation, acceleration or recurrence of which was contributed to by the employment.

In disease cases the determination of a claim will normally be based on specialist medical opinion which, on the balance of probability, points to a casual relationship between the condition under claim and the employment.

In cases where exposure to radiation is alleged, subject both to an employee's exposure to radiation in the employment having been established, and to the condition under claim being consistent with such exposure, then, in the absence of specialist evidence to the contrary, the employment will be deemed to have been a contributing factor to the contraction of the condition.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has Australia the dubious distinction of levying the highest rate of airport departure tax of the major tourism-orientated countries.
(2) Is departure tax levied at airports in the United Kingdom, the United States of America, Canada, Greece, Italy, Germany, or any other country that furnishes Australia with tourist dollars.

(3) Will the Treasurer consider eliminating this iniquitous levy, dubbed by American tourists as the 'suffering sucker tax' and so recognise the importance to Australia of the tourism industry; if not, will the Treasurer consider mitigating the effects of the tax by exempting tourists and family vacationers as well as families visiting migrant relatives in Australia and migrants visiting relatives overseas.
(4) Will the Treasurer also ensure that any revenue gained from the tax be used to boost the tourism industry and upgrade airport facilities instead of disappearing into consolidated revenue.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) Departure taxes, in one form or another, are levied in over 100 countries many of whom provide Australia with tourist traffic. The form of the tax varies and it is often incorporated in the price of the ticket so that travellers may be unaware of the existence and size of the impost. While the total amount of tax in overseas countries varies significantly, Australia certainly does not have the highest total. For example, New Zealand charges a levy of $35 on all adult tickets purchased there, together with an airport tax of $2.

(3) The departure tax was introduced in the 1978-79 Budget as a general revenue raising measure. In the three years since then the tax appears to have had little, if any, impact on tourist travel to and from Australia and the tax is not significant when seen in relation to the total costs of international travel. The exclusions suggested by the honourable senator would seriously limit the usefulness of the tax as a general revenue raising measure; they would also add major complications to its administration.

(4) As a general principle, Government expenditures are best allocated according to the priority attaching to those needs and not simply on the basis of revenue collected from a particular tax.
