TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 27 October 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Gentlemen's Agreement of 1936 referred to in the answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 588 (Hansard, 14 October 1981, page 1277) subsequently been altered; if so, when, and what is the text of the current agreement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: In the period since 1936, the Loan Council has made a large number of amendments to the Gentlemen's Agreement to accommodate the developments which have occurred in financial markets, and to reflect the evolution in Loan Council procedures. The text of the current agreement (approved at Loan Council's June 1981 meeting) follows:
AUSTRALIAN LOAN COUNCILBORROWING BY SEMI-GOVERNMENT AND LOCAL AUTHORITIESTHE 'GENTLEMEN'S AGREEMENT'
(As amended to 19 June 1981 at 117th Meeting of Loan Council.)

Members of the Australian Loan Council have agreed that the following conditions will apply to future borrowings of Commonwealth and State semi-government and local authorities. These arrangements consolidate amendments made to the original Gentlemen's Agreement since 1936 and, where necessary, modify the Agreement (as amended) in the light of Loan Council practices that have developed since then.
A. BORROWING PROGRAMS

(i) In the case of semi-government and local authorities constituted under the laws of the Commonwealth or a State which propose to raise more than $1,200,000 in any one year, all loans issued either in the form of new money or for the purpose of conversion or redemption of maturing debt are to be subject to the authority of the Treasurer of the Commonwealth or of the Premier or Treasurer of the State concerned as to the amount, terms, time and place of issue.

(ii) The Commonwealth and each State agree to submit to the Chairman of the Loan Council, before the close of the preceding financial year, the new money borrowing program for each semi-government and local authority proposing to borrow more than $1,200,000 in the form of new money during the forthcoming financial year. After the Loan Council has decided the maximum aggregate amounts to be borrowed by such authorities in the Commonwealth and each State, the Commonwealth and each State agree to submit to the Chairman by 31 October each year a program for the financial year for each authority within the overall limits decided by the Loan Council. Unless the Loan Council decides otherwise, these programs will constitute the final borrowing programs for each authority during the year concerned. Transfers of unused borrowing allocations between individual authorities will be allowed subsequently within this financial program subject to the specific approval of the Loan Council in each case.

(iii) The Commonwealth and each State also agree to submit to the Chairman, before the close of the preceding financial year, a program of borrowing for the purpose of conversion or renewal of maturing loans by the authorities referred to in clause (ii), together with programs of borrowings of more than $1,200,000 during the year for conversion or renewal purposes by other semi-government and local authorities. No additions will subsequently be made to this program without the specific approval of the Loan Council. The Chairman may agree to additions to the program on the recommendation of the State Premier concerned where these have been omitted due to oversight. Details of such approval given by the Chairman will be circulated to the Loan Council each month.

(iv) The borrowing programs referred to in clauses (ii) and (iii) above will be considered by the Loan Council in conjunction with its consideration of the borrowing programs for the Commonwealth and State Governments.

(v) the borrowing programs referred to in clauses (ii) and (iii) will cover the total proposed borrowing for a complete financial year, and any approvals granted by the Loan Council for those borrowings will, if not availed of, lapse at the close of the financial year concerned, unless otherwise specifically determined by the Loan Council.

(vi) The amount, terms, time and place of issue of each loan raised to finance the borrowing programs referred to in clauses (ii) and (iii) will be fixed by the Premier or Treasurer concerned, in consultation with the Chairman, who will consult the Members of the Loan Council before giving his decision. If, subsequent to Loan Council's decision, there is a change in maximum semi-government interest rates, the Premier or Treasurer concerned may, without further reference to Loan Council, approve a change to the interest rates for a public loan proposal (provided that the new rates comply with the revised maxima and that all other terms and conditions as approved by Loan Council remain unchanged) and may vary the time of the loan by not more than five working days. The Premier or Treasurer concerned may also give his decision on proposals for private borrowings by semi-government and local authorities without consultation with other Members of the Loan Council, provided the terms and conditions of proposals comply with the terms and conditions of similar proposals which have previously received unanimous Loan Council Approval. Details of such borrowings will be reported to the Chairman each month by each Premier or Treasurer for circulation to the Loan Council.

(vii) Authorities with borrowing programs, referred to in clauses (ii) and (iii) and exceeding $100 million in any year, should not seek to raise more than two-thirds of their total programs in the first half of the financial year and limit approaches to the market to a minimum interval of two months, unless there are special factors which justify exceptions.
(viii) The Chairman may agree to the transfer of borrowing allocations from one authority to another on the recommendation of the State Premier concerned.
Details of such approvals given by the Chairman will be circulated to the Loan Council each month.

(ix) Unless the Loan Council decides otherwise, there will be no overall limit on borrowings by authorities with programs of not more than $1,200,000. The terms of such borrowings will be determined by the Treasurer of the Commonwealth for Commonwealth authorities and by the Premiers or Treasurers of the States for their respective authorities. These terms will be in accordance with those currently being approved by the Loan Council for authorities borrowing more than $1,200,000 during the year.

(x) Monthly returns of aggregate new money borrowings by semi-government and local authorities in the Commonwealth and in each State with programs of 1,200,000 or less in the form of new money are to be furnished each month to the Chairman, who will circulate them to the other Members.
B. TERMS AND CONDITIONS FOR INDIVIDUAL LOANS
(i) Interest rates.

The margins by which the maximum interest rates offered by semi-government and local authorities may exceed the yields to maturity on Commonwealth bonds of comparable maturities will be as fixed by the Loan Council from time to time.
(ii) Placement fees-public issues.

(iv) Excess subscriptions.
Excess subscriptions to public loans are not to be retained unless otherwise specifically determined by the Loan Council.
(v) Period for which public loans open for subscription.
The period for a public cash or cash and conversion loan will be a maximum of two weeks and for conversion only loans a maximum of one week unless otherwise decided by Loan Council.
(vi) Results of public loans.

The Commonwealth and each State agree to inform the Chairman of the results of each public loan as soon as practicable after the closing date of the loan. Where subscriptions have been received in excess of the amount offered, the Chairman is to be informed at the same time whether these amounts have been returned to subscribers.
(vii) Private borrowings when public loans are open for subscription.

Between the opening date of a public loan and seven days after the closing of that loan, the Commonwealth and each State agree that they will not submit to the Chairman details of proposed private borrowings by the same authority unless they are satisfied that the amount of the private offer would not be available for subscription to the public loan.
(viii) Counter sales.
(a) Counter sales of securities by semi-government and local authorities, when approved by the Loan Council, will be permitted to remain open for a period specifically approved by the Loan Council.
(b) The interest rates of counter sales will be those appropriate at the time for public loans raised by semi-government and local authorities.

(c) The amount of each approval for counter sales which is debited against borrowing programs for semi-government and local authorities will be limited to the amount actually received as advised to the Chairman at the close of the period approved for the sales.
(ix) Publicity.

No public announcement or release of the proposed dates, terms and conditions of public loans of semi-government and local authorities will be made until Loan Council approval of such dates, terms and conditions has been obtained. In the case of opening and closing dates, an announcement may be made, if desired, as soon as a tentative allocation has been made by the Chairman.
(x) Loan Council approval.

(a) The Commonwealth and each State agree that, when submitting proposals for private borrowing by semi-government and local authorities for Loan Council consideration, they will inform the Chairman if any of the terms and conditions as submitted are subject to review before the funds are to be received by the borrower. The Chairman is also to be informed if the terms of the transaction are not to be finally settled within one month of the date of the submission.

(b) Unless the Chairman is advised to the contrary, the Loan Council will assume that all proposals for private borrowings by semi-government and local authorities have been firmly taken up and such amounts will be debited against the borrowing program of the authority for that year.

(c) Public borrowing proposals by semi-government and local authorities will only be debited against borrowing programs to the extent that actual offers are made on the market. Proposals for public loans which are withdrawn after Loan Council approval has been obtained will not be debited against programs.
(d) Any variation of the terms on which a loan has been approved is to be submitted for Loan Council consideration.
(xi) Timing of borrowings for conversion purposes.
Borrowings may be arranged for conversion purposes during a period of 3 months prior to the maturity date of the securities concerned.
(xii) Loans with settlement deferred or by instalments.
Borrowings may be made with settlement deferred up to 3 months from the date of approval provided that the interest rate is firm at the time of approval.
(a) Private Borrowings.

Private loans may be taken up by instalments provided the first instalment is received within 3 months, that the balance is received within twelve months of the date of approval of the terms, that the interest rate is firm at the time of approval and that the whole of the proceeds are taken up within the financial year to which the borrowing relates.
(b) Public Borrowing.
Public loans may be taken up by instalments provided that the whole of the proceeds are taken up within 3 months of the last day of the loan.
(xiii) Overseas borrowing.
(a) All proposals for overseas borrowings by semi-government and local authorities will be submitted to the Chairman before any commitment is entered into.

(b) Overseas financing by authorities through buyer credit arrangements entered into by them and through the incurring of any obligations by them to contractors under supplier credit arrangements which involve overseas lenders, if confined to the financing of direct overseas expenditure by the authority or by the contractor or supplier for the acquistion, delivery and services in respect of capital equipment to be provided under the relevant purchase or construction contract, will not be charged against borrowing programs aproved by the Loan Council for semi-government and local authorities and are not subject to Loan Council approval.
(c) Except as the Loan Council, by unanimous decision, otherwise decides, all other borrowings under this clause shall be charged against such approved borrowing programs.

(d) Other than for trade credit arrangements to finance direct overseas expenditure referred to in (b) above and such other borrowings as the Loan Council by unanimous decision exempts from this requirement, Loan Council approval will be required:
(i) before any approach is made to obtain overseas borrowings; and
(ii) for the terms and conditions of borrowings subsequently arranged.

(e) Where approval to approach overseas sources of funds is given by the Loan Council, there shall be full consultation with the Chairman prior to the submission of any resulting firm borrowing proposal to the Loan Council for approval.

(f)Any borrowing under this clause is also subject to any resolution relevant to that borrowing, which may be made by unanimous decision of the Loan Council from time to time concerning overseas borrowings by semi-government and local authorities.
(xiv) Deferred payment contracts.

Except as provided under clause B(xiii) all proposals by semi-government and local authorities for domestic financing of public works projects or purchasing capital equipment by instalment payments, or by deferred payments, are to be circulated for consideration by the Loan Council where the amount involved is in excess of $1,000,000 and payments are to be made over a period of more than three years from the completion of the project or from the receipt of the equipment being purchased. It is agreed that all such proposals shall be put out to tender and that, when each proposal is submitted for Loan Council consideration, an assurance will be given that this requirement has been satisfied.

Accordingly, the income limits under the new health insurance arrangements were set at relatively high levels so that those people who fail to qualify can reasonably be regarded as being in a position to contribute towards their health care costs.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Sales Tax on Pet Food for Guide Dogs

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September 1981 (Hansard, page 756) Senator McIntosh asked me, as Minister for Social Security, the following question:

ANSWER.PARA: Will blind invalid pensioners be forced to pay the full sales tax on pet food for their guide dogs or is any provision being made for them to claim exemption.
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

I have sought the advice of the Commissioner of Taxation on the operation of this particular sales tax provision, and have been advised that sales tax on pet food applies only to animals kept as domestic pets. It is accepted that guide dogs are kept not as domestic pets but as a means of assisting the safe movement of blind persons from place to place. Blind persons will be entitled, therefore, to claim exemption for pet food for their guide dogs.

To claim exemption a blind person will have to supply a standard form exemption certificate to his supplier. There is, however, no requirement in the sales tax law which compels a retailer such as a supermarket to accept such an exemption certificate. To obtain the exemption it may be more practical for a blind person to deal with a wholesaler of pet food or a specialist pet food supplier.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 September 1981 (Hansard, page 848) Senator Gietzelt asked the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that a minute from the Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner, which was presented to Cabinet in May of this year, expressed satisfaction with the progress of the case for the deregistration of the Builders Labourers Federation as prepared by the Minister's predecessor, Mr Peacock? If this is so, why did the Minister inform the House of Representatives and one of its Estimates committees that the case was still incomplete and unsatisfactory? Does the Minister not concede that a case of misrepresentation could be made in respect of one of these two areas?
The Minister for Industrial Relations has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The matters raised by the honourable senator have been canvassed at length-in the House of Representatives Estimates Committee E on 8 September 1981, in my reply to the question without notice in the House on 15 September, and in debate in the House on 22 and 23 September. While I refer the honourable senator to the full record of those debates, I can advise him that on 8 September I informed the House of Representatives Estimates Committee E, referring to the state of preparedness of the Government's application for deregistration of the ABCE & BLF when I became Minister responsible, as follows:

'It was utterly impossible to lodge the proceedings in April because they simply were not prepared. The whole material was not gathered and that material was not in a form appropriate for filing of any documentation. What I sought from the Department was an intensification of effort in the gathering of that material and in the preparation of it.'
In amplifying this comment in the House of Representatives on 23 September, I made the following additional remarks:

'After I took over responsibility I was briefed by my officers on 22 April. I was informed then of the procedure that they were applying as a task force to gather the material, to put it into-to use a legal term-proofs of evidence or statements of prospective witnesses, to have those matters checked out by Counsel, to have them returned to the task force and then, to have them put by the task force under supervision of legal Counsel from the Victorian Bar and a senior officer of the Attorney-General's Department, into affidavit form. Anyone who has practised law, any member of the public who can understand this kind of thing, will readily appreciate the amount of meticulous and detailed work that has to go into the preparation of a case of this kind. I think anyone would understand the veracity of the statement I made to Estimates Committee E and to this House that in April it was utterly impossable to have that case in a state of readiness for filing in April.
There is in my mind a clear distinction between progress in the gathering of material and having a case prepared to the point of its being ready to file in the Court.'
There is neither contradiction nor misrepresentation in the statements by me to the House of Representatives or its Estimates Committee or in any advice given by me to the Government.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 887) Senator Reid asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Transport a question without notice concerning the views of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association of Australia on the General Aviation Study.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Transport has provided me with the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I have noted the view of the Aircraft Owners and Pilots Association (AOPA) on the General Aviation Study. The report was the result of careful and thorough research. It has provided a significant contribution to our knowledge of the general aviation industry. However, as you will be aware, the Government has decided not to accept the recommendations on cost recovery, but to continue its previous practice of deciding on levels of air navigation charges annually in the Budget context.

I am also aware that AOPA is seeking an independent enquiry into my Department. In recent years, my Department has been subjected to many reviews. To name only a few of the more significant investigations, there was the Government industry study in Departmental costs and revenues in the early 1970s the Coombs review of Government expenditures in 1973, the Bland Report in 1976, and the Industry Review Committee in the mid 1970s, in which the industry participated in depth. More recently, of course, there has been the review of Commonwealth functions conducted by Ministers. In addition, my Department is subject to reviews by the Government, the Parliament and its committees, the central agencies of government and through the Aviation Industry Advisory Council and other consultative arrangements with the air transport industry.

It is also pertinent to note that between 1975 and 1980 there was a reduction in the Department's staffing levels from 11,415 to 11,269. On the other hand, hours flown by the industry increased from about 1.6 million to 2.2 million in the same period.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September (Hansard, page 895) Senator Watson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Education, a question without notice concerning a shortage of academics in the computer sciences area.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Education has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Eight hundred new Postgraduate Awards were made available by the Commonwealth for 1981 for higher degree study in a wide range of disciplines including Computer Science and Information Science. This was an increase of 100 on the number of new Awards provided for 1980. The Awards are competitive with selection based on academic merit in the case of Research Awards, for Ph.D. and Masters' courses by research at universities, and on employment experience as well as academic merit in the case of Course Awards, for Masters' degrees by coursework at universities, and Advanced Education Institution Awards, for Masters' courses at colleges of advanced education. Graduates seeking to undertake higher degrees in the computing field may compete for Awards on equal terms with those wishing to undertake higher degrees in other areas.

Although it is not policy to differentiate between the various sections of postgraduate study in allocating the Awards, there has in fact been an increase in recent years in the number of Award holders who are studying in the Computer Science-Information Science area. The numbers in recent years have been 16 in 1977, 18 in 1978, 21 in 1979, 23 in 1980 and 24 in 1981.
Under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme (TEAS) benefits are available to students wishing to undertake a wide variety of postgraduate diploma courses in computer sciences and similar fields.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 (Hansard, pages 979 and 980) Senator Robertson asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Communications been drawn to a report in last Sunday's Canberra Times dealing with the Special Broadcasting Service? Does he agree with the claim that ethnic broadcasting is producing 'laundered' news and avoids debate of public issues, even when these are of particular concern to migrants? Has his attention been drawn also to reports of the recent Australian Council of Trade Union Congress which carried a resolution deploring the present Government's practice of using government-funded ethnic media as a propaganda outlet, censoring information and preventing discussions on matter of public interest, particularly with regard to the trade union movement?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I am aware of the report in the Canberra Times and the resolution of the Australian Council of Trade Unions Congress to which the honourable senator refers. However, I am advised that the Special Broadcasting Service endeavours to provide a comprehensive and balanced news service to each of the language groups serviced by ethnic radio stations 2EA and 3EA.

To this end, guidelines have been developed by and for the SBS news service to ensure accuracy, impartiality and responsibility. Overall responsibility for the selection of news items provided by the News Department for presentation on individual language programs rests with the language group coordinator, who is required to assess the information value of the material provided in the context of its interest and relevance to the community being served.

The Government, through the SBS, makes no attempt to interfere in the normally accepted mode of collection or presentation of news as provided by the radio stations, nor does it in any way inhibit the presentation of debates on issues of public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 (Hansard, page 982), Senator Townley asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Health, a question without notice concerning the dispensing of pharmaceuticals under the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme.

ANSWER.PARA: The Minister for Health has provided the following information:

The maximum quantity and number of repeats for pharmaceutical benefit items are recommended by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC). The PBAC is the independent statutory body established under the National Health Act to advise me, as Minister for Health, on matters concerning the listing of pharmaceutical benefits. The PBAC provides expert medical advice on such matters.

In recommending maximum quantities for pharmaceutical benefits the PBAC follows a general guideline that for the treatment of an acute condition the maximum quantity should provide sufficient medication for a course of treatment; for the treatment of chronic conditions the PBAC recommends sufficient, at normal dosage levels, for one month's treatment and two repeats. In some cases five repeats are recommended.
The PBAC considers that its guidelines on maximum quantities and repeats are consistent with sound medical practice and the requirement for regular medical review of patients with chronic illness.
In the light of the honourable senator's question the PBAC has reviewed its policy on maximum quantities and reaffirmed that its guidelines represent a good basic policy.

The matter of a possible reduction in the prescription fee or patient contribution for various categories of people, including children and the chronically ill, was considered by the Government in the context of the 1981-82 Budget. However, in the present economic climate, the Government could not see its way clear to further add to the group of patients who enjoy concessions in relation to the payment of patient contributions towards the cost of pharmaceutical benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 13 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1085), Senator Crichton-Browne asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

As I understand the position, the aircraft were badly damaged during the Second World War and were converted to components, which means essentially that they have been stripped of useful parts and abandoned in that remote and almost totally inaccessible part of Western Australia since 1945. I further understand that it is the intention of the group which has recovered the aircraft to restore one for static display and that it is hopeful, using other parts it has, of restoring the other to flying condition. If that is the case it will be only the second Beaufighter aircraft in the world flying today. I ask the Minister: Firstly, to whom do the aircraft belong and by what critieria do they claim legal ownership? Secondly, will the Government consider vesting ownership of the aircraft in the restoration group which has recovered them; provided they are made available on display to the Australian people?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following information, additional to that which I gave at the time:
(1) The property remains in the Commonwealth as original owner, unless proof of abandonment is clear. This onus will be upon the interested third party.

(2) The Commonwealth may enter into a loan agreement with an interested party. This will confer exclusive rights to a group to restore and use the aircraft for a given period. Ownership, however, remains with the Commonwealth. It has not been, and will not be, the Commonwealth's intention to pass title to other parties concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 22 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1537) Senator Robertson asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Defence been drawn to an article appearing in yesterday's issue of the Sun headed 'Joke Force'? The article states, inter alia:
The total defence effort in Darwin consists of one functional but slow RAAF Caribou transport plane, four naval patrol boats and just over 100 regular soldiers.

Would the Minister not agree that this level of deployment is laughable and will he take steps to see that Australia's northern coastline is more appropriately protected? At present inadequate funds are being made available to Norforce, the reservist force currently being developed to service the north. Will the Minister provide a more appropriate level of funds for this group?
The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

A new patrol boat base to support the Fremantle class patrol boats is under construction in Darwin and is due for completion in late 1982. The new Fremantle class boats will increase the surveillance capabilities in Northern Australia. Attack class patrol boats presently provide regular patrols of the Australian fishing Zone while RAAF P3 Orion aircraft conduct aerial surveillance staging through Darwin and Learmonth.

Norforce replaced the Darwin based Army Reserve Unit, 7 Independent Rifle Company on 1 July 1981. I can assure the honourable senator that sufficient funds have been made available for Norforce which is being progressively developed as a new concept, with the specific role of surveillance and reconnaissance in the north. The force has a currently planned strength of 40 regular and 280 reserve soldiers.
A fighter squadron is planned to be based in Darwin and this together with a new airfield to be constructed at Derby will enhance Defence capabilities in northern Australia.

Daily aerial surveillance of the northern Australian littoral is provided by civil contract aircraft under the control of the Australian Coastal Surveillance Centre. Civil contract aircraft also cover the offshore approaches to Darwin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 28 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1715) Senator MacGibbon asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, refers to the defence statement made last week by the Minister for Defence in relation to the acquisition of a replacement carrier for HMAS Melbourne. The details of such investigations must remain confidential for a variety of reasons: they involve the security of Australia and, frequently, of our allies; they impinge upon information of a commercial nature which has been provided in confidence; and the public disclosure of this material could impair our negotiating position when dealing with prospective suppliers of the equipment.
I shall be making a statement to Parliament in due course on the new carrier, and will provide detailed reasons for any decision at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 19 August 1981:

(3) When will the system start operation.
(4) Does the Government intend retrenching the present security staff; if so, why, and with effect from when; if not, what alternative work will be offered to them.
(5) Will a private firm be responsible for the building's security; if so, does the Government believe this is appropriate for a building containing taxation, social security and other records.

As a result of a review of security arrangements at the Centre, it was concluded by my Department that a satisfactory level of security could be provided more economically by the operation of a computer controlled security system to govern entry to the building for part of the time now serviced by a full-time watchman.

(5) My Department will continue to be responsible for the building's security, although a private firm will provide manned surveillance to the extent necessary, and will monitor security systems. TALK.START.PARA: —On 23 September 1981 (Hansard, page 896) Senator Elstob asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Recently a decision was made to proceed with the demanning of 12 lighthouses in the next 5 years.
(1) Can the Minister assure the Senate that Transport Australia sufficiently canvassed community interests before planning this program?
(2) Were the safety of shipping lanes, search and rescue operations, coastal surveillance work and environmental protection matters, all facets of a lightkeeper's work, taken into consideration?

(3) Will the Minister guarantee that lighthouses of historical importance will not fall into disrepair and be lost as part of our heritage once they are automated and pass out of the constant supervision of a keeper?
The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(1) The five-year rolling program for updating the Commonwealth network of Navigational aids currently includes the automation of 12 lightstations. Although automation does allow a station to be demanned this does not necessarily follow in every case. Every lighthouse is examined on its merits and the level of manning is only decided after full consultation with all interested parties.

(2) The safety of shipping lanes is not affected by automation or unmanning. Search and rescue, coastal surveillance and environmental protection, despite the fact that some use is made of them from time to time on an opportunity basis, are not facets of a lightkeeper's work; they are, nonetheless, taken into consideration when manning levels are being decided.
(3) Authorities responsible for heritage considerations are consulted and no building of historical importance will be allowed to deteriorate.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Television Station Licence Fees: Amendment of Money Bills

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 September 1981 (Hansard, page 980) Senator Siddons asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communitions, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is it true, as reported this morning in the Age, that the Government is seeking legal advice on how it can amend one of its own money Bills in the Senate in order to reduce television company licence fees that were to be increased in this Budget? If the Government succeeds in finding a legal means by which the Senate can amend money Bills, will the Minister inform the Senate of this discovery? If the report is correct, can the Minister explain why the Government has changed its mind on the matter?
The Minister for Communications has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

I refer the honourable senator to my second reading speech on the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Bill 1981, at page 2286 in Hansard, which explains the course the Government has followed in revising the schedule by which licence fees are set both for radio and for television licensees. I take this opportunity to reassure the honourable senator that all licences on which a higher fee became payable under measures announced in the Budget will also incur a higher fee under the provisions of the Broadcasting Stations Licence Fees Bill 1981 and the Television Stations Licence Fees Bill 1981.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October 1981 (Hansard, page 1362) Senator Mulvihill asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: By way of preface, I refer him to the vision splendid, which I think he shares with me and every other New South Wales senator, of the Moore Park Engineers Depot being vacated and it, together with the Sports Ground and the Sydney Cricket Ground No. 2, being merged into a modern sports stadium. Since this was promised by Lance Barnard and Senator Withers when he held the Administrative Services portfolio, can the Minister advise what has happened? When is the Army moving out? When can Sydney achieve this vision splendid?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

Under the land exchange arrangements between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Governments the Moore Park Engineers Depot was transferred to the State on 20 March 1981 and is leased back to the Commonwealth pending a relocation of the Army facility.
As part of the agreement between the governments the Commonwealth is to make its best endeavours to vacate the land no later than 1983 and is working towards this objective.
When the Commonwealth vacates the land the achievement of the vision splendid will be a matter for the State.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 November 1981 (Hansard, page 1927) Senator Martyr asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is he aware of an excellent submission from the Western Australian Minister for Police and Traffic proposing that the new Australian police college be located in Perth? Is the Minister aware that the full co-operation of the Western Australian Institute of Technology has been obtained so that the police college would be a special department? Is the Minister also aware that there were no submissions from other States for the siting of this college? Will the Minister see that speedy consideration is given to this Western Australian application? Finally, will he ask that all other Ministers do all they can to see that the Australian police college comes to Perth?
The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

One of the agenda items for the forthcoming meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council in Hobart on 20 November is the upgrading and relocation of the Australian Police College, which is presently located at Manly, New South Wales.
Under this agenda item, Council is to consider a report from the Working Party on the Relocation of the Australian Police college. This report incorporates the Western Australian submission.
The upgrading and relocation of the College is a matter for consideration and decision by Council, of which the Commonwealth is but one member.
